question: Question 1 Two units, rated at 100 MW and 150 MW , are enabled for economic load dispatch. When the overall incremental cost is 10,000 Rs./MWh, the units are dispatched to 50 MW and 80 MW respectively. At an overall incremental cost of [latex]10,600 \mathrm{Rs} . / \mathrm{MWh}[/latex], the power output of the units are 80 MW and 92 MW , respectively. The total plant MW-output (without overloading any unit) at an overall incremental cost of 11,800 Rs./MWh is ___________ (round off to the nearest integer).
solution:
Let’s define: Unit 1 outputs:
At 10,000 Rs./MWh → [latex] P_1 = 50\ \text{MW} [/latex]
At 10,600 Rs./MWh → [latex] P_1 = 80\ \text{MW} [/latex] Unit 2 outputs:
At 10,000 Rs./MWh → [latex] P_2 = 80\ \text{MW} [/latex]
At 10,600 Rs./MWh → [latex] P_2 = 92\ \text{MW} [/latex] We are to find outputs at 11,800 Rs./MWh using extrapolation for both units (assuming linearity of power vs incremental cost curve). Step 1: Find slope of output with respect to cost for each unit Unit 1 slope:
[latex] \frac{80 - 50}{10,600 - 10,000} = \frac{30}{600} = 0.05\ \text{MW per Rs./MWh} [/latex] Unit 2 slope:
[latex] \frac{92 - 80}{10,600 - 10,000} = \frac{12}{600} = 0.02\ \text{MW per Rs./MWh} [/latex] Step 2: Extrapolate to 11,800 Rs./MWh Cost increase: [latex] 11,800 - 10,600 = 1,200\ \text{Rs./MWh} [/latex] Unit 1 output:
[latex] P_1 = 80 + (0.05)(1200) = 80 + 60 = 140\ \text{MW} [/latex]
(but Unit 1 is rated for 100 MW max ⇒ limit to 100 MW) Unit 2 output:
[latex] P_2 = 92 + (0.02)(1200) = 92 + 24 = 116\ \text{MW} [/latex]
(but Unit 2 is rated for 150 MW ⇒ no limit hit) Step 3: Total Output [latex] P_{\text{total}} = 100 + 116 = \boxed{216\ \text{MW}} [/latex] Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{216} [/latex]

Question 6 During a power failure, a domestic household uninterruptible power supply (UPS) supplies AC power to a limited number of lights and fans in various rooms. As per a Newton-Raphson loadflow formulation, the UPS would be represented as a
solution: In a power system load-flow analysis: A Slack bus (swing bus) is defined with specified voltage magnitude and angle. It balances the active and reactive power in the network. A PV bus has specified real power [latex]P[/latex] and voltage magnitude [latex]V[/latex], while [latex]Q[/latex] is calculated. A PQ bus has specified real power [latex]P[/latex] and reactive power [latex]Q[/latex], and [latex]V[/latex] and angle [latex]\theta[/latex] are calculated. A PQV bus is not a standard term in load-flow analysis. In this case, the UPS supplies power and maintains the system voltage, effectively acting as the reference. Hence, it is modeled as a Slack bus in Newton-Raphson load-flow formulation.

Question 8 For the three-bus lossless power network shown in the figure, the voltage magnitudes at all the buses are equal to 1 per unit (pu), and the differences of the voltage phase angles are very small. The line reactances are marked in the figure, where [latex] \alpha, \beta, \gamma [/latex] and [latex] x [/latex] are strictly positive. The bus injections [latex] P_{1} [/latex] and [latex] P_{2} [/latex] are in pu. If [latex] P_{1}=m P_{2} [/latex], where [latex] m > 0 [/latex], and the real power flow from bus 1 to bus 2 is 0 pu. then which one of the following options is correct?
solution:
[latex]
\begin{aligned}
P_{1} & =m P_{2} \\
P_{1} & =\frac{1 \times 1}{\beta x} \sin \theta \\
P_{2} & =\frac{1 \times 1}{\gamma x} \sin \theta \\
\frac{1 \times 1}{\beta x} \sin \theta & =m \frac{1 \times 1}{\gamma x} \sin \theta \\
\frac{1}{\beta} & =\frac{m}{\gamma} \Rightarrow \gamma=m \beta
\end{aligned}
 [/latex]

Question 18 A 20 MVA, 11.2 kV, 4-pole, 50 Hz alternator has an inertia constant of
15 MJ/MVA. If the input and output powers of the alternator are 15 MW and
10 MW, respectively, the angular acceleration in mechanical [latex] degree/s^2[/latex] is
__________. (round off to nearest integer)
solution:
We have, swing equation [latex]\frac{2HS}{\omega _s}\frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2}=P_a [/latex] Put the values, [latex] \begin{aligned}
\frac{2 \times 15 \times 20}{360 \times 50}\frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2}&=15-10\\
\frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2}&=\frac{5 \times 360 \times 50}{2 \times 15 \times 20}\\
&=150 \text{ electric degree per} sec^2\\
\frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2}&=\alpha =\frac{2}{4} \times 150 \text{ Mech. degree/}sec^2\\
&=75\text{ Mech. degree/}sec^2
\end{aligned} [/latex]

Question 19 Two generating units rated for 250 MW and 400 MW have governor speed
regulations of 6% and 6.4%, respectively, from no load to full load. Both the
generating units are operating in parallel to share a load of 500 MW. Assuming free
governor action, the load shared in MW, by the 250 MW generating unit is
_________. (round off to nearest integer)
solution:
Let no-load frequency is 50 Hz. Draw the curve : From the curve, [latex]  \begin{aligned}
\frac{50-f}{3}&=\frac{P_1}{250} \;\;\;..(1)  \\
\frac{50-f}{3.2}&=\frac{P_2}{400} \;\;\;..(2) 
\end{aligned}[/latex] From eq. (1) & (2), [latex] \begin{aligned}
\frac{3P_1}{250}&= \frac{3.2P_2}{400}  \\
3P_1&=2P_2\;\;\;...(3)
\end{aligned} [/latex] Given: 
[latex]P_1+P_2=500[/latex] From eq. (3), [latex] P_1+1.5P_1=500[/latex] [latex] P_1=200MW[/latex]

generation of plant 1 and plant 2 in MW, respectively, are

[latex] \frac{dC_1}{dP_1}=IC_1=6+0.008P_1[/latex] [latex] \frac{dC_2}{dP_2}=IC_2=a+0.006P_2[/latex] For optimum generation, [latex] IC_1=IC_2=\lambda[/latex] Therefore, 
[latex]6+0.008P_1=8 [/latex] [latex]P_1=250MW [/latex] Given, 
[latex]P_1+P_2=550MW [/latex] [latex] P_550-250=300MW[/latex]

question: Question 27 In the figure shown, self-impedances of the two transmission lines are [latex]1.5j\:p.u[/latex] each, and [latex]Z_{m}=0.5j \:p.u[/latex] is the mutual impedance. Bus voltages shown in the figure are in p.u. Given that [latex]\delta>0[/latex], the maximum steady-state real power that can be transferred in p.u from Bus-1 to Bus-2 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{e q}&=\frac{L_{1} L_{2}-M^{2}}{\left(L_{1}+L_{2}-2 M\right)} \\ X_{\mathrm{eq}}&=\frac{1.5 \times 1.5-0.5^{2}}{1.5+1.5-2 \times 0.5}=1 \mathrm{p.u.} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{\max }&=\frac{|E||V|}{1}\\ P_{\max }&=|E||V| \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 Two single-core power cables have total conductor resistances of [latex]0.7\;\Omega[/latex] and [latex]0.5\;\Omega[/latex], respectively, and their insulation resistances (between core and sheath) are [latex]600\;M\Omega[/latex] and [latex]900\;M\Omega[/latex], respectively. When the two cables are joined in series, the ratio of insulation resistance to conductor resistance is ___________[latex]\times 10^{6}[/latex].
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \left(R_{\text {eq }}\right)_{\text {conductor }} &=0.7+0.5=1.2 \Omega \\ \left(R_{\text {eq }}\right)_{\text {in }} &=\frac{1}{\left(R_{e q}\right)_{\text {in }}}=\frac{1}{\left(R_{\text {in }}\right)_{1}}+\frac{1}{\left(R_{\text {in }}\right)_{2}}=\frac{1}{900 \times 10^{6}}+\frac{1}{600 \times 10^{6}} \\ \left(R_{\mathrm{eq}}\right)_{\text {in }} &=360 \times 10^{6} \Omega\\ \frac{\left(R_{\text {eq }}\right)_{\text {in }}}{\left(R_{\text {eq }}\right)_{\text {conductor }}}&=\frac{360 \times 10^{6}}{1.2}=300 \times 10^{6} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 29 Two generators have cost functions [latex]F_{1}[/latex] and [latex]F_{2}[/latex]. Their incremental-cost characteristics are [latex]\dfrac{dF_{1}}{dP_{1}}=40+0.2P_{1}[/latex] [latex]\dfrac{dF_{2}}{dP_{2}}=32+0.4P_{2}[/latex] They need to deliver a combined load of [latex]260 \text{~MW}[/latex]. Ignoring the network losses, for economic operation, the generations [latex]P_{1}[/latex]
 and [latex]P_{2}[/latex] (in [latex]\text{MW}[/latex]) are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I C_{1} &=I C_{2} \\ 40+0.2 P_{1} &=32+0.4 P_{2} \\ 0.4 P_{2}-0.2 P_{1} &=8 \\ P_{2}+P_{1} &=260 \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving equation (i) and (ii), [latex] P_{1}=160 \mathrm{MW} ; P_{2}=100 \mathrm{MW}[/latex]

question: Question 30 Consider a power system consisting of N number of buses. Buses in this power system are categorized into slack bus, PV buses and PQ buses for load flow study. The number of PQ buses is [latex]N_{L}[/latex]. The balanced Newton-Raphson method is used to carry out load flow study in polar form. [latex]\text{H, S, M, and R}[/latex] are sub-matrices of the Jacobian matrix J as shown below: [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \Delta P\\ \Delta Q \end{bmatrix}=J\begin{bmatrix} \Delta \delta \\ \Delta V \end{bmatrix}, \text{where}\: J=\begin{bmatrix} H & S\\ M &R \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The dimension of the sub-matrix M is
solution: [latex]\left[\begin{array}{l} \Delta P \\ \Delta Q \end{array}\right]=J\left[\begin{array}{l} \Delta \delta \\ \Delta V \end{array}\right] \text { where } J=\left[\begin{array}{ll} H & S \\ M & R \end{array}\right][/latex] For size of M Row = No. of unknown variables of [latex]Q=N_{L}[/latex] Column = No. of variable which has [latex]\delta=N_{L}+\left(N-1-N_{L}\right) [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} &=N-1\\ \text{So}, \quad\text{ size of }M&=N_{L} \times(N-1) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 31 Bus 1 with voltage magnitude [latex]V_1 = 1.1 p.u.[/latex] is sending reactive power [latex]Q_{12}[/latex] towards bus
2 with voltage magnitude [latex]V_2 = 1 p.u.[/latex] through a lossless transmission line of reactance
X. Keeping the voltage at bus 2 fixed at 1 p.u., magnitude of voltage at bus 1 is changed,
so that the reactive power [latex]Q_{12}[/latex] sent from bus 1 is increased by 20%. Real power flow
through the line under both the conditions is zero. The new value of the voltage
magnitude, [latex]V_1[/latex], in p.u. (rounded off to 2 decimal places) at bus 1 is _______ .
solution: With real power zero, load angle [latex]\delta =0[/latex] with initial values,  [latex]V_{1}=1.1, \; \; \; V_{2}=1[/latex] [latex]Q_{12}=\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{X}-\frac{V_{1}V_{2}}{X}\sin \delta [/latex] [latex]\, \, =\frac{(1.1)^{2}}{X}-\frac{1.1\times 1}{X}\sin 0=\frac{0.11}{x}[/latex] With increased value of voltage, new value of [latex]\; Q_{12}=1.2Q_{12},\; \;  V_{2}=1[/latex] [latex] 1.2\, Q_{12}=\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{X}-\frac{V_{1}\times 1}{X}=1.2\times \frac{0.11}{X}[/latex] [latex] V_{1}^{2}-V_{1}-0.132=0 [/latex] [latex]V_{1}=1.12,\; \;  -0.118[/latex] Hence the practical value in per unit,[latex]V_{1}=1.12[/latex] p.u.

question:
Question 34 A lossless transmission line with 0.2 pu reactance per phase uniformly distributed along
the length of the line, connecting a generator bus to a load bus, is protected up to 80%
of its length by a distance relay placed at the generator bus. The generator terminal
voltage is 1 pu. There is no generation at the load bus. The threshold pu current for
operation of the distance relay for a solid three phase-to-ground fault on the transmission
line is closest to:
solution: [latex]I_{f}=\frac{1}{Z_{Th}}=\frac{1}{0.2}[/latex] =5 pu for 100% of line Relay is operated for 80% [latex]Z_{f}=0.8\, Z_{t}\Rightarrow 0.8\times 0.2=0.16\, p.u.[/latex] For 80% of line, [latex]I_{f}=\frac{1}{0.16}=6.25\: p.u.[/latex]

question: Question 35 In  a  132  kV  system,  the series inductance up to the  point  of  circuit  breaker  locationis  50 mH. The shunt capacitanceat the circuit breaker terminal is 0.05 [latex]\mu F[/latex]. The critical value of resistance in ohms required to be  connected across the circuit breaker contacts which will give no transient oscillation is_____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L&=50mH\\ C&=0.05\mu F\\ R_{cr}&=\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{\frac{L}{C}}\\ &=\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{\frac{50 \times 10^{-3}}{0.05 \times 10^{-6}}}\\ &=500\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 In the single machine infinite bus system shown below, the generator is delivering the real power  of  0.8pu  at 0.8 power  factor  lagging  to  the  infinite  bus.  The  power  angle  of  the generator in degrees (round off to one decimal place) is _________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} X &=0.25+0.2+0.4||0.4 \\ &=0.45+0.2=0.65pu \\ P&=V_{pu} \times I_{pu} \cos \phi \\ 0.8 &=1 \times I_{pu} \times 0.8 \\ I_{pu} &= 1pu\\ E &= V+jI_aX_s\\ &=1+1\angle -36.86^{\circ} \times j0.65 \\ &= 1.484 \angle 20.51^{\circ}pu\\ \delta &= 20.51^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 37 A 30 kV, 50 Hz, 50 MVA generator has the positive, negative, and zero sequence reactancesof 0.25 pu, 0.15 pu, and 0.05 pu, respectively. The neutral of the generator is grounded with a reactance so that the fault current for a bolted LG fault and that of a bolted three-phase fault at the generator terminal are equal. The value of grounding reactance in ohms (round off to one decimal place) is ______

Question 38 A  three-phase  50  Hz,  400  kV  transmission  line  is  300  km  long.  The  line  inductance  is 1 mH/km per phase, and the capacitance is 0.01 [latex]\mu F/km[/latex] per phase. The line is under open circuit condition at  the  receiving  end  and  energized  with  400  kV  at  the  sending  end, the receiving end line voltage in kV (round off to two decimal places) will be ___________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_s&= 400kV\\ l&=300km\\ L_1&=1mH/km/phase\\ C_1&=0.01 \mu F/km/phase\\ v&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{L_1C_1}}\\ &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 \times 10^{-3} \times 0.01 \times 10^{-6}}}\\ &=3.16 \times 10^5 km/sec\\ \beta '&=\frac{2 \pi f l}{v}\\ &=\frac{2 \pi \times 50 \times 300}{3.16 \times 10^5}=0.29\\ A&=1-\frac{\beta ^2}{2}\\ &=1-\frac{(0.29)^2}{2}=0.955\\ V_R&=\frac{V_S}{A}=\frac{400}{0.955}=418.85kV \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 The total impedance of the secondary winding, leads, and burden of a 5 A CT is 0.01 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. If the fault current is 20 times the rated primary current of the CT, the VA output of the CT is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{sec}&=5 \times 20=100A \\ V &=I_{sec}R =100 \times 0.01\\ &=1V \\ \text{VA } &\text{output of the CT} \\ &= VI_{sec}=100 \times 1\\ &= 100VA \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 Five  alternators  each  rated  5  MVA,  13.2  kV  with  25%  of  reactance  on  its  own  base  are connected in parallel to a busbar. The short-circuit level in MVA at the busbar is_________
solution: Net reactance of parallel connection, [latex]\begin{aligned} X&=\frac{0.25}{5}=0.05\;p.u.\\ I_{SC}&=\frac{1}{X}=\frac{1}{0.05}=20\; p.u.\\ \text{SC MVA}&=20 \times 5\\ &=100 \text{ MVA} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 The [latex]Y_{bus}[/latex] matrix of a two-bus power system having two identical parallel lines connected between them in pu is given as [latex]Y_{bus}=\begin{bmatrix} -j8 &j20 \\ j20 & -j8 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The magnitude of the series reactance of each line in pu (round off up to one decimal place) is ___________
solution: [latex]Y_{12}=-(y_{12})=-j20[/latex] Series admittance of each line [latex]=\frac{Y_{12}}{2}=\frac{-j20}{2}=-j10[/latex] Series reaactance of each line [latex]=\frac{1}{-j10}=j0.1 \; p.u.[/latex]

question: Question 42 In the circuit shown below, the switch is closed at t=0. The value of [latex]\theta[/latex] in degrees which will give the maximum value of DC offset of the current at the time of switching is
solution: If the switch is closed at t=0 in series R-L circuit. Then the circuit current i(t) expression is [latex]\begin{aligned} i(t)&=\left \{ \frac{-V_m}{\sqrt{R^2+X_L^2}}\sin (\theta -\phi ) \right \}e^{-t/\tau }\\ &+\frac{V_m}{\sqrt{R^2+X_L^2}}\sin (\omega t -\phi ) \end{aligned}[/latex] The first term of expression indicates DC offset current. For maximum value of DC offset current, the angle should be [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} -\left ( \theta -\tan ^{-1}\left ( \frac{\omega L}{R} \right ) \right )&=90^{\circ}\\ -\left ( \theta -\tan ^{-1}\left ( \frac{377 \times 10 \times 10^{-3}}{3.77} \right ) \right )&=90^{\circ}\\ (\theta -45^{\circ})&=-90^{\circ}\\ \theta &=-45^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 43 A three-phase load is connected to a three-phase balanced supply as shown in the figure. If [latex]V_{an}=100\angle 0^{\circ} V[/latex], [latex]V_{bn}=100\angle -120^{\circ}V[/latex] and [latex]V_{cn}=100\angle -240^{\circ} V[/latex] (angles are considered positive in the anti-clockwise direction), the value of R for zero current in the neutral wire is ___________[latex]\Omega[/latex] (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: From the given voltages, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_R&=\frac{V_{RN}}{R}=\frac{100\angle 0^{\circ}}{R}\\ I_Y&=\frac{V_{YN}}{jX_L}=\frac{100\angle 120^{\circ}}{j10}\\ &= 10\angle -210^{\circ}\\ I_B&=\frac{V_{BN}}{-jX_C}=\frac{100\angle -240^{\circ}}{-j10}\\ &=10\angle -150^{\circ}\\ \text{For }\; I_N&=0\\ I_R+I_Y+I_B&=0\\ \frac{100}{R}+&10\angle -210^{\circ}+10\angle -150^{\circ}=0\\ R&=5.77\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 44 The per-unit power output of a salient-pole generator which is connected to an infinite bus,
is given by the expression,  [latex]P= 1.4 \sin\delta + 0.15 \sin 2 \delta[/latex], where [latex]\delta[/latex] is the load angle. Newton-Raphson method is used to calculate the value of [latex]\delta[/latex] for P = 0.8 pu. If the initial guess is
30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex], then its value (in degree) at the end of the first iteration is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P(\delta )&=1.4 \sin \delta +0.15 \sin 2\delta =0.8\\ &=1.4 \sin \delta +0.15 \sin 2\delta -0.8=0\\ P'(\delta )&=\frac{d}{d\delta }(P(\delta ))\\ &=1.4 \cos \delta +0.30 \cos 2\delta \text{Given, } \delta _0&=30^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] By using Newton Raphson method for single variable, [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta \delta &=\delta _1-\delta _0=-\frac{f(\delta _0)}{f'(\delta_0)}=-\frac{P(\delta _0)}{P'(\delta_0)}\\ &=\delta _1 -30^{\circ}=-\frac{1.4 \sin 30^{\circ}+0.15 \sin 60^{\circ} -0.8}{1.4 \cos 30^{\circ}+0.3 \cos 60^{\circ}}\\ &=\delta _1 -30^{\circ}=-0.0219 \; red =-1.26^{\circ}\\ &=\delta _1 =28.74^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 45 Consider the two bus power system network with given loads as shown in the figure. All
the values shown in the figure are in per unit. The reactive power supplied by generator [latex]G_1[/latex] and [latex]G_2[/latex] are [latex]Q_{G1}[/latex] and [latex]Q_{G2}[/latex] respectively. The per unit values of [latex]Q_{G1}, Q_{G2}[/latex], and line reactive
power loss ([latex]Q_{loss}[/latex]) respectively are
solution:
At [latex]G_2[/latex] load demand is 20 pu, [latex]G_2[/latex] supplies only 15 pu. Remaining supplied by [latex]G_1[/latex] through transmission line. [latex]\begin{aligned}
P_S&=\left | \frac{V_SV_R}{X_L} \right | \sin \delta \\
5&=\frac{1 \times 1}{0.1} \sin \delta \\
\delta &=30^{\circ}\\
Q_S&=\frac{V_S^2}{X_L}-\frac{V_SV_R}{X_L} \cos \delta \\
&=\frac{1^2}{0.1}-\frac{1 \times 1 }{0.1} \cos 30^{\circ}\\
&=1.34 p.u.\\
Q_R&=\left | \frac{V_SV_R}{X_L} \right | \cos \delta -\left | \frac{V_R^2}{X_L} \right | \\
5&=\frac{1 \times 1}{0.1} \cos 30^{\circ}-\frac{1^2}{0.1} \\
&=-1.34p.u.\\
Q_{loss}&+Q_S-Q_R\\
&=1.34-(-1.34)=2.68p.u.\\
\text{At }G_1: \; Q_{G1}&=Q_{load}+Q_S\\
&=5+1.34=6.34p.u.\\
\text{At }G_2: \; Q_{G2}&=Q_{load}-(-Q_R)\\
&=10-(-1.34)=11.34p.u.
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 The positive, negative and zero sequence impedances of a three phase generator are [latex]Z_{1},Z_{2}[/latex] and [latex] Z_{0}[/latex] respectively. For a line-to-line fault with fault impedance [latex]Z_{f}[/latex] ,the fault current is    [latex]I_{f1}=kI_{f}[/latex] , where [latex]I_{f}[/latex] is the fault current with zero fault impedance. The relation between [latex]Z_{f}[/latex] and k is
solution: For LL fault: Without [latex]Z_f[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given, } I_{f1}&=k \times I_f \\ \frac{\sqrt{3} E_g}{Z_1+Z_2+Z_f} &=\left ( \frac{\sqrt{3} E_g}{Z_1+Z_2} \right )k \\ Z_1+Z_2&=k(Z_1+Z_2+Z_f) \\ Z_f &=\frac{(Z_1+Z_2)(1-k)}{k} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 47 A 1000 x 1000 bus admittance matrix for an electric power system has 8000 non-zero
elements. The minimum number of branches (transmission lines and transformers) in this
system are _____ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: Number of buses =1000 No. of non-zero element = 8000 [latex]\begin{aligned} \% \text{ sparsity}&=\% x\\ &=\frac{\text{Number of zero element}}{\text{Total number of elements }}\\ &=\frac{10^6 -8000}{10^6}=0.992\\ \text{NO. of Tr-lines}&=\frac{N^2(1-x)-N}{2}\\ &=\frac{1000^2(1-0.992)-1000}{2}\\ &=3500 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 48 The positive, negative and zero sequence impedances of a 125 MVA, three-phase, 15.5 kV,
star-grounded, 50 Hz generator are j0.1 pu, j0.05 pu and j0.01 pu respectively on the
machine rating base. The machine is unloaded and working at the rated terminal voltage. If
the grounding impedance of the generator is j0.01 pu, then the magnitude of fault current
for a b-phase to ground fault (in kA) is __________ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: For LG fault, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{f\;p.u.}&=\frac{3V_{Th}}{Z_1+Z_2+Z_0+3Z_n}\\ &=\frac{3 \times 1 }{0.1+0.05+0.01+3(0.01)}\\ &=15.789\; p.u.\\ I_{base}&=\frac{P}{\sqrt{3}\cdot V_L}\\ &=\frac{125 \times 10^6}{\sqrt{3} \times 15.5 \times 10^3}\\ &=4656.05A\\ I_f&=I_{f\;p.u.}\cdot I_{base}\\ &=15.789 \times 4656.05\\ &=73516.538=73.52kA \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 49 The series impedance matrix of a short three-phase transmission line in phase coordinates
is [latex]\begin{bmatrix} Z_{s} & Z_{m} &Z_{m} \\ Z_{m}& Z_{s}& Z_{m}\\ Z_{m}& Z_{m}& Z_{s} \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. If the positive sequence impedance is [latex](1 + j10)\Omega[/latex], and the zero
sequence is [latex](4 + j31)\Omega[/latex], then the imaginary part of [latex]Z_{m}[/latex] (in [latex]\Omega[/latex]) is ______(up to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_1&=(1+j10)\Omega \\ Z_0&=(4+j31)\Omega \\ \text{we know,}\\ Z_1&=Z_s-Z_m\\ Z_0&=Z_s+2Z_m\\ Z_1-Z_0&=-3Z_m\\ Z_m&=\frac{Z_0-Z_1}{3}\\ &=\frac{4+j31-1-j10}{3}\\ &=\frac{3+j21}{3}\\ &=1+j7 \end{aligned}[/latex] The imaginary part of [latex]Z_m[/latex] is 7.00.

question: Question 50 Consider a lossy transmission line with [latex]V_{1} \; and  \; V_{2}[/latex] as the sending and receiving end voltages, respectively. Z and X are the series impedance and reactance of the line, respectively. The steady-state stability limit for the transmission line will be
solution: With only x: [latex]P_{max}=\left | \frac{V_1V_2}{x} \right |[/latex] With Lossy Tr, Line [latex]P=\left | \frac{V_1V_2}{z} \right | \cos (\beta -\delta )-\left | \frac{AV_2^2}{z} \right |\cos (\beta -\delta )[/latex] Therefore, with Lossy Line [latex]P_{max} \lt \left | \frac{V_1V_2}{x} \right |[/latex]

question:
Question 51 For the balanced Y-Y connected 3-Phase circuit shown in the figure below, the line-line voltage
is 208 V rms and the total power absorbed by the load is 432 W at a power factor of 0.6 leading. The approximate value of the impedance Z is
solution: For star connection, [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{3-\phi }&=\left | \frac{V_L^2}{z} \right | \cos \phi \\ Z&=\frac{V_L^2}{P_{3-\phi }} \cos \phi \\ &=\frac{208^2 }{430} \times 0.6 \\ \cos \phi &=0.6 \text{ lead}\\ \phi &=53.13^{\circ}\\ \therefore \; Z&=60\angle -53.13^{\circ}\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 52 A 3-phase, 2-pole, 50 Hz, synchronous generator has a rating of 250 MVA, 0.8 pf lagging. The
kinetic energy of the machine at synchronous speed is 1000 MJ. The machine is running
steadily at synchronous speed and delivering 60 MW power at a power angle of 10 electrical
degrees. If the load is suddenly removed, assuming the acceleration is constant for 10 cycles,
the value of the power angle after 5 cycles is ________ electrical degrees.
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
 S&=250 MVA \\ 
 \cos \phi &=0.8 \\ 
K.E. &=1000MJ \\ 
 P_e&= 60MW\\ 
 \delta _0&=10^{\circ} \\ 
 t&=10\; cycles\\
&=\frac{10}{50}=0.2\; sec \\ 
 t&=5\; cycle =0.1sec \\ 
 \text{Load}&\text{ is removed,} \\ 
 P_e&=0 \\ 
 P_a&=P_m-P_e \\ 
P_m &=60MW \\ 
 M&=\frac{HS}{180f}=\frac{K.E.}{180f} \\ 
 &= \frac{1000}{180 \times 50}=0.111\\ 
 \frac{d^2 \delta }{dt^2}&=\frac{P_a}{M}=545.45 \text{ ele.degree}/s^2 \\ 
 \text{Integrating}&\text{ the above eq.} \\
\int \left ( \frac{d^2 \delta }{dt^2} \right )dt&=\int \frac{P_a}{M}dt=545.45 \times t\\
\text{Integrating}&\text{ tit once again with dt} \\
&=545.45 \times t(dt)\\
\delta &=\frac{545.45 \times t^2}{2}=2.7^{\circ}\\
\text{So, new}&\text{ value of power angle}\\
&=10^{\circ}+2.7^{\circ}=12.7^{\circ}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 53 Two generating units rated 300 MW and 400 MW have governor speed regulation of 6% and
4% respectively from no load to full load. Both the generating units are operating in parallel to
share a load of 600 MW. Assuming free governor action, the load shared by the larger unit is
_______ MW.
solution: Given: speed regulation of generating unit is from no load to full load. Hence, the rated frequency (50 Hz) will be common for both units at no load nad will drop to lower value as loaded to full load. Let,  [latex]P_1=[/latex] Load shared by 400 MW machine [latex]P_2=[/latex] Load shred by 300 MW machine For 400 MW machine drop in frequency from no load to full load [latex]=\frac{50 \times 4}{100}=2 Hz[/latex] New frequecy of operation of 400 MW machine, [latex]f_1=50-\frac{2}{400}P_1[/latex] For 300 MW machine drop in frequency from no load to full load [latex]=\frac{50 \times 6}{100}=3 Hz[/latex] New frequecy of operation of 300 MW machine, [latex]f_2=50-\frac{3}{300}P_2[/latex] we also know, [latex]\begin{aligned} P_1+P_2&=600 \\\ (\text{Load shared }& \text{between shared units})\\ P_2&=600-P_1 \\ f_1&=f_2=f \\ (\text{Units operatio }& \text{ is in parallel})  \\ 50-\frac{2}{400}P_1 &=50-\frac{3}{300}(600-P_1) \\ \frac{P_1}{200}&=\frac{600-P_1}{100} \\ 100P_1 &=200(600-P_1) \\ P_1&=1200-2P_1\\ 3P_1&=1200\\ P_1&=400 MW \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 54 Consider an overhead transmission line with 3-phase, 50 Hz balanced system with conductors located at the vertices of an equilateral triangle of length [latex]D_{ab}=D_{bc}=D_{ca}=1m[/latex] as shown in figure below. The resistance of the conductors are neglected. The geometric mean radius (GMR) of
each conductor is 0.01m. Neglecting the effect of ground, the magnitude of positive sequence reactance in [latex]\Omega[/latex]/ km (rounded off to three decimal places) is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} X_L&=2 \pi f L\\&=2 \pi f \times 2 \times 10^{-7} \ln \left ( \frac{D_m}{D_s} \right )\\ &=2 \pi \times 50 \times 2 \times 10^{-7} \ln \left ( \frac{1}{0.01} \right )\\ &=2.89 \times 10^{-4}\Omega /m\\ X_L&=0.289 \Omega /km \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 55 The nominal- [latex]\pi[/latex] circuit of a transmission line is shown in the figure. Impedance [latex]Z=100\angle 80^{\circ}\Omega[/latex] and reactance X=3300[latex]\Omega[/latex]. The magnitude of the characteristic
impedance of the transmission line, in [latex]\Omega[/latex], is _______________. (Give the answer up to one
decimal place.)
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z&=100\angle 80^{\circ}\Omega \\ X&=3300\Omega \\ \frac{y}{2}&=\frac{1}{X}=\frac{1}{3300} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} y&=\frac{2}{3300}=6.06 \times 10^{-4}\\ Z_C&=\sqrt{\frac{Z}{y}}=\sqrt{\frac{100}{6.06 \times 10^{-4}}}\\ &=406.2\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 56 In a load flow problem solved by Newton-Raphson method with polar coordinates, the size of
the Jacobian is 100x100. If there are 20 PV buses in addition to PQ buses and a slack bus, the
total number of buses in the system is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} [J]&=[2n-m-2] \\ 100&= [2n-20-2]\\ n&= 61 \end{aligned}[/latex] Total number of buses =n=61

Question 58 A load is supplied by a 230 V, 50 Hz source. The active power P and the reactive power Q
consumed by the load are such that  [latex]1 kW \leq P \leq 2kW [/latex] and [latex]1{kVAR}  \leq Q \leq {kVAR}[/latex]. A capacitor connected across the load for power factor correction generates 1 kVAR reactive power. The worst case power factor after power factor correction is
solution: Load p.f. [latex]\begin{aligned} \cos \phi &=\cos \left [ \tan ^{-1}\frac{Q}{P} \right ]\\ &=\cos \left [ \tan^{-1}\frac{1}{1} \right ]\\ &=0.707 \text{ lag}\\ Q_c&=P[\tan \phi _1 -\tan \phi _2]\\ 1&=(\tan \cos ^{-1} 0.707- \tan \phi _2)\\ \phi _2&=45^{\circ}\\ \Rightarrow \; \cos \phi _2&=0.707 \text{ lag} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 60 The figure shows the single line diagram of a power system with a double circuit transmission
line. The expression for electrical power is  [latex]1.5 sin\delta[/latex], where [latex]\delta[/latex] is the rotor angle. The system is operating at the stable equilibrium point with mechanical power equal to 1 pu. If one of the transmission line circuits is removed, the maximum value of [latex]\delta[/latex] as the rotor swings, is 1.221 radian. If the expression for electrical power with one transmission line circuit removed is [latex] P_{max}  sin\delta[/latex], the valueof  [latex] P_{max} [/latex], in pu is _________.
solution: Using equal area criteria: [latex]A_1=A_2[/latex] [latex]\int_{\delta _0}^{\delta _c}(P_{m0}-P_{max1} \sin \delta )d\delta =\int_{\delta _c}^{\delta _2}(P_{max1} \sin \delta -P_{m0})d\delta[/latex] By solving above integration, [latex]P_{max1}=\frac{P_{m0}(\delta _2-\delta _0)}{\cos \delta _0- \cos \delta _2}[/latex] Given data: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{m0} &=1pu \\ P_e&= 1.5 \sin (\delta _0)=P_{m0}=1pu\\ \delta _0&41.8^{\circ}=0.7295\; rad \\ \delta _2 &=1.221\; rad =96.95^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Substitute above values in above equation, [latex]P_{max1}=\frac{1(1.221-0.7295)}{\cos 41.8- \cos 69.95}=1.220 p.u.[/latex]

question: Question 61 The bus admittance matrix for a power system network is [latex]\begin{bmatrix} -j39.9 & j20 & j20\\ j20 & -j39.9 & j20\\ j20 & j20 & -j39.9 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]pu There is a transmission line, connected between buses 1 and 3, which is represented by the circuit shown in figure. If this transmission line is removed from service, What is the modified bus admittance matrix?
solution: [latex]Y_{bus}=\begin{bmatrix} -j39.9 & j20 & j20\\ j20 & -j39.9 &j20 \\ j20 & j20 & -j39.9 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] Reactance is eliminated in between Bus 1 and 3. [latex]\begin{aligned} Y_{11(new)} &=-j39.9-\frac{1}{j0.05}-j0.05 \\ &=-j19.95 \\ Y_{33(new)} &=-j39.9-\frac{1}{j0.05}-j0.05 \\ &=-j19.95 \\ Y_{13(new)} &=Y_{31}=-y_{13}-\frac{1}{j0.05} \\ Y_{31(new)} &=-j20-\frac{1}{j0.05}=0 \end{aligned}[/latex] So, modified admittance matrix is, [latex]=\begin{bmatrix} -j19.95 & j20 &0 \\ j20 & -j39.9 & j20\\ 0 & j20 & -j19.95 \end{bmatrix}\;pu[/latex]

Question 64 A source is supplying a load through a 2-phase, 3-wire transmission system as shown in figure

Similarly for phase-b the instantaneous voltage and current are [latex]V_{bn}=220cos (100\pi t)[/latex]V and [latex]i_{b}=10cos( 100\pi t[/latex]A, respectively The total instantaneous power flowing form the source to the load is

Question 66 At no load condition, a 3-phase, 50 Hz, lossless power transmission line has sending-end and
receiving-end voltages of 400 kV and 420 kV respectively. Assuming the velocity of traveling wave to be the velocity of light, the length of the line, in km, is ____________.
solution: At no load, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_s&=AV_R\\ 400 &=A420\\ A&=\frac{400}{420}=0.9524\\ A&=1+\frac{YZ}{2}\\ &=1+\frac{(r+j\omega L)()g+j\omega C)}{2}\\ &\text{For lossless line,}\\ r&=0,g=0\\ \text{then,}\\ A&=1-\frac{(\omega C)(\omega L)}{2}\\ \beta l&=\sqrt{\omega L\omega C}\\ A&=0.9524=1-\frac{\beta ^2l^2}{2}\\ \beta l&=0.3085\\ \beta &=\frac{0.3085}{l}\\ \frac{V}{f}&=\frac{2\pi}{\beta }\\ \frac{3 \times 10^5}{50}&=\frac{2 \pi}{\left ( \frac{0.3085}{l} \right )}\\ l&=294.52km \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 67 The single line diagram of a balanced power system is shown in the figure. The voltage magnitude at the generator internal bus is constant and 1.0 p.u. The p.u. reactances of different components in the system are also shown in the figure. The infinite bus voltage magnitude is 1.0 p.u. A three phase
fault occurs at the middle of line 2. The ratio of the maximum real power that can be transferred during the pre-fault condition to the maximum real power that can be transferred under the faulted condition is _________.
solution: The ratio[latex]=\frac{P_1}{P_2}=\frac{X_1}{X_2}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} 1.\; \Rightarrow \; \;&\frac{j0.35 \times j0.6}{j1.2} &=j0.175 \\ 2.\; \Rightarrow \; \; &\frac{j0.6 \times j0.25}{j1.2} &=j0.125 \\ 3.\; \Rightarrow \; \; &\frac{j0.35 \times j0.25}{j1.2} &=j0.0729 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} X_{12}&=X_2\\ &=j0.375+j0.125+\frac{j0.375\times j0.125}{j0.0729}\\ &=j1.1430\;p.u.\\ \frac{P_1}{P_2}&=\frac{X_2}{X_1}=\frac{j1.1430}{j0.5}=2.286 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 68 A 50 MVA, 10 kV, 50 Hz, star-connected, unloaded three-phase alternator has a synchronous reactance of 1 p.u. and a sub-transient reactance of 0.2 p.u. If a 3-phase short circuit occurs close to the generator terminals, the ratio of initial and final values of the sinusoidal component of the short circuit current is ________.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I''&=\frac{E_g}{X_d''};\; I=\frac{E_g}{X}\\ \frac{I''}{I}&=\frac{X}{X_d''}=\frac{1.0}{0.2}=5.0\; p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 69 The inductance and capacitance of a 400 kV, three-phase, 50 Hz lossless transmission line are 1.6 mH/km/phase and 10 nF/km/phase respectively. The sending end voltage is maintained at 400 kV. To maintain a voltage of 400 kV at the receiving end, when the line is delivering 300 MW load, the shunt compensation required is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_n&=\sqrt{\frac{L}{C}} \\ &= \sqrt{\frac{1.6 \times10^{-3}}{10 \times 10^{-9}}}\\ &= 400\Omega \\ \text{SIL} &=\frac{400 \times 400}{400}=400 MW \end{aligned}[/latex] In the second case SIL decreases means [latex]Z_n[/latex] increasess. [latex]Z_n[/latex] increases with increase in inductance 'L'. So, it is inductive. Load [latex]\lt [/latex] SIL means, line behaves capacitive to compensate it inductor to be placed.

Question 72 A single-phase transmission line has two conductors each of 10 mm radius. These are fixed at a center-to-center distance of 1 m in a horizontal plane. This is now converted to a three-phase transmission line by introducing a third conductor of the same radius. This conductor is fixed at an equal distance D from the two single-phase conductors. The three-phase line is fully transposed. The positive sequence inductance per phase of the three-phase system is to be 5% more than that of the inductance per conductor of the single-phase system. The distance D, in meters, is _______.
solution: In first case, [latex]\begin{aligned} L_1&=2 \times 10^{-7} \ln \frac{D}{r}\\ &=2 \times 10^{-7} \ln \left ( \frac{100}{0.7788} \right )\\ &=0.97\mu H/m\\ L_2&=1.05 \times 0.97=1.0185 \mu H/m\\ L_2&=2 \times 10^{-7} \ln \left ( \frac{\sqrt[3]{D^2 \times 100}}{0.7788} \right ) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \ln \left ( \frac{\sqrt[3]{D^2 \times 100}}{0.7788} \right )&=\frac{1.0185 \times 10^{-6}}{2 \times 10^{-7}}\\ &=5.0925\\ e^{5.0925}&= \frac{\sqrt[3]{D^2 \times 100}}{0.7788} \\ D&=142.7cm=1.427m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 74 A 30 MVA, 3-phase, 50 Hz, 13.8 kV, star-connected synchronous generator has positive, negative and zero sequence reactances, 15%, 15% and 5% respectively. A reactance ([latex]X_n[/latex]) is connected between the neutral of the generator and ground. A double line to ground fault takes place involving phases 'b' and 'c', with a fault impedance of j0.1 p.u. The value of [latex]X_n[/latex] (in p.u.) that will
limit the positive sequence generator current to 4270 A is _________.
solution: Base current, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_B&=\frac{30 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3} \times 13.8}=1255.109A\\ I_f&=4270A\\ I_{p.u.}&=\frac{4270}{1255.109}=3.402p.u.\\ I_{g1}&=\frac{E_a}{X_1+(X_2||X_0)}\\ &\text{where, }\\ X_0&=X_0+3(Z_n+Z_f)\\ X_0&=3Z_n+0.35\\ 3.402&=\frac{1.0}{0.15+\frac{0.15 \times (3Z_n+0.35)}{0.15+3Z_n+0.35}}\\ &\text{Solving the equation,}\\ Z_n&=1.07 \;p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 75 A three-phase cable is supplying 800 kW and 600 kVAr to an inductive load. It is intended to supply an additional resistive load of 100 kW through the same cable without increasing the heat
dissipation in the cable, by providing a three-phase bank of capacitors connected in star across the load. Given the line voltage is 3.3 kV, 50 Hz, the capacitance per phase of the bank, expressed in microfarads, is ________.
solution: [latex]\text{KVA}_1=\sqrt{800^2+600^2}=100 \text{ KVA}[/latex] Without excessive heat dissipation means current should be constant (i.e.) KVA erating must be constatn. In second case active power, P=800+100=900 KW Reactive power in second case, [latex]Q_2=\sqrt{1000^2-900^2}=435.889 \text{ KVAR}[/latex] Reactive power supplied by the three phase bank = 600-435.889 =164.44 KVAR [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_{bank}/ph&=\frac{164.11}{3}=54.7 \text{ KVAR} \\ V/ph&= \frac{3.3}{\sqrt{3}}=1.9051 \text{ KV}\\ Q_c/ph&=\frac{(V/ph)^2}{X_C} \\ X_C&=\frac{(1.9052 \times 10^3)^2}{54.7 \times 10^3} \\ &= 66.36\; W\\ C&= \frac{1}{2 \pi f X_C}\\ &=\frac{1}{2 \pi \times 50 \times 66.36}\\ &=47.96 \mu F \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 76 The magnitude of three-phase fault currents at buses A and B of a power system are 10 pu and 8 pu,
respectively. Neglect all resistances in the system and consider the pre-fault system to be unloaded.
The pre-fault voltage at all buses in the system is 1.0 pu. The voltage magnitude at bus B during a three-phase fault at bus A is 0.8 pu. The voltage magnitude at bus A during a three-phase fault at bus B, in pu, is ________.
solution: Voltage at bus B after 3-phase fault at A=0.8 p.u. [latex]\begin{aligned} V_B &=V_{(prefault)}-Z_{12} \times I_{f(A)} \\ 0.8&= 1.0-Z_{12} \times 10 \\ Z_{12} &=0.02 p.u. \\ V_A &=V_{(prefault)}-Z_{12}I_{f(B)} \\ V_A&=1.0-(0.02 \times 8) \\ &= 0.84p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

respective powers [latex]P_1 \; and \; P_2[/latex] in MW, and are given by [latex]\frac{dC_{1}}{dP_{1}}=0.2 P_{1}+50 [/latex] [latex]\frac{dC_{2}}{dP_{2}}=0.24P_{2}+40 [/latex] where [latex]20MW\leq P_{1}\leq 150MW [/latex] [latex]20 MW \leq P_{2} \leq 150MW[/latex]. Question 81 A 3-bus power system network consists of 3 transmission lines. The bus admittance matrix of the uncompensated system is [latex]\begin{bmatrix} -j6 & j3&j4 \\ j3& -j7 & j5\\ j4 & j5 & -j8 \end{bmatrix}pu.[/latex] If the shunt capacitance of all transmission lines is 50% compensated, the imaginary part of the [latex]3_{rd}[/latex] row [latex]3_{rd}[/latex] column element (in pu) of the bus admittance matrix after compensation is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Y_{BUS}&=\begin{bmatrix} y_{11}+y_{12}+y_{13} &-y_{12} &-y_{13} \\ -y_{21} & y_{21}+y_{22}+y_{23} & -y_{23}\\ -y_{31}& -y_{32} & y_{31}+y_{32}+y_{33} \end{bmatrix} \\ &= \begin{bmatrix} -j6 & j3 & j4\\ j3& -j7 & j5\\ j4 & j5 & -j8 \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}[/latex] By comparing for [latex]Y_{33}[/latex]element [latex]\begin{aligned} y_{31}+y_{32}+y_{30}&=-j8\\ (-j4)+(-j5)+y_{30}&=-j8\\ y_{30}&=j1 \end{aligned}[/latex] After compensating with 50% of shunt capacitance [latex]=j1 \times 0.5=j0.5[/latex] Hence, new value [latex]=-j8-j0.5=-j8.5[/latex]

question: Question 83 A sustained three-phase fault occurs in the power system shown in the figure. The current and voltage phasors during the fault (on a common reference), after the natural transients have died down, are also shown. Where is the fault located?

question: Question 84 A 50 Hz generating unit has H-constant of 2 MJ/MVA. The machine is initially operating in steady state at synchronous speed, and producing 1 pu of real power. The initial value of the rotor angle [latex]\delta[/latex] is 5[latex]^{\circ}[/latex], when a bolted three phase to ground short circuit fault occurs at the terminal of the generator. Assuming the input mechanical power to remain at 1 pu, the value of [latex]\delta[/latex] in degrees, 0.02 second after the fault is _________.
solution:
Let [latex]3-\phi[/latex] fault occurs at t=0 [latex]\Rightarrow \; P_e=0\text{ for }t\geq 0^+[/latex] Now, swing equation for [latex]t\geq 0^+[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
\frac{2H}{\omega _s}\frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2} &=P_m \\ 
 \frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2}&= \frac{P_m \omega _s }{2H}\\ 
\frac{d\delta }{dt}&= \frac{P_m \omega _s }{2H}t+C\\ 
 C=\left.\begin{matrix}
\frac{d\delta }{dt}
\end{matrix}\right| _{t=0^+}&=\omega (t=0^+)-\omega _s\\ 
 C=\omega _s-\omega _s&=0\;(\omega (t-0^+)=\omega _s) \\ 
 \frac{d\delta }{dt}&=\frac{P_m \omega _s }{2H}t \\ 
 \Rightarrow \; \delta &= \frac{P_m \omega _s }{4H}t^2+C'\\ 
 C'&= \delta |_{t=0^+}=\delta _0\\ 
\delta  &= \frac{P_m \omega _s }{4H}t^2+\delta _0\\
\text{Now in problem,}\\
\delta (t=0.02)&\\
&=\frac{1 \times 2  \times 180  \times 50 \times 0.02^2 +5^{\circ}}{4 \times 2}\\
&=5.9^{\circ}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 85 Determine the correctness or otherwise of the following Assertion [a] and the Reason [r]. Assertion: Fast decoupled load flow method gives approximate load flow solution because it uses several assumptions. Reason: Accuracy depends on the power mismatch vector tolerance.

options.B: Both [a] and [r] are true but [r] is not the correct reason for [a].

question: Question 86 Consider the economic dispatch problem for a power plant having two generating units. The fuel costs in Rs/MWh along with the generation limits for the two units are given below: [latex]C_{1}(P_{1})=0.01{P_{1}}^2+30P_{1}+10[/latex];   [latex]100MW\leq P_{1} \leq 150MW[/latex] [latex]  C_{2}(P_{2})=0.05{P_{2}}^2+10P_{2}+10[/latex];  [latex]100MW\leq P_{2} \leq 180MW[/latex] The incremental cost (in Rs/MWh) of the power plant when it supplies 200 MW is ______ .
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C_1&=0.01P_1^2+30P_1+10\\ \frac{dC_1}{dP_1}&=2 \times 0.01P_1+30\\ &=0.02P_1+30\\ C_2&=0.05P_2^2+10P_2+10\\ \frac{dC-2}{dP_2}&=0.1P_2+10\\ \text{For optimum } &\text{incremental cost,}\\ \frac{dC_1}{dP_1}&=\frac{dC_2}{dP_2}\\ 0.02P_1+30&=0.1P_2+10\\ 0.02P_1-0.1P_2&=-20 \;\;...(i)\\ \text{Given, }P_1+P_2&=200 \;\;...(ii)\\ \text{Solving } & \text{equation (i) and (ii),}\\ P_2&=200, P_1=0\\ \text{But the }& \text{range of }P_1 \text{ and }P_2 \text{ are specified as}\\ 100MW \leq & P_1 \leq 150MW\\ 100MW \leq & P_2 \leq 180MW\\ \text{hence, }& P_2=200 MW \text{ is not valid}\\ \text{so, both }& P_1 \text{ and } P_2 \text{ are operating at}\\ P_1=100,P_2=100\;& \Rightarrow \; P_1+P_2=200\\ IC_1=\frac{dC_1}{dP_1}&=0.02 \times P_1+30=32 Rs/MW\\ IC_2=\frac{dC_2}{dP_2}&=0.1 \times P_2+10=20 Rs/MW \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 87 Base load power plants are P: wind farms. Q: run-of-river plants. R: nuclear power plants. S: diesel power plants.

Question 88 The figure shows the single line diagram of a single machine infinite bus system. The inertia constant of the synchronous generator H = 5 MW-s/MVA. Frequency
is 50 Hz. Mechanical power is 1 pu. The system is operating at the stable equilibrium point with rotor angle [latex]\delta[/latex] equal to 30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex]. A three phase short circuit fault occurs at a certain location on one of the circuits of the double circuit transmission line. During fault, electrical power in pu is  [latex]P_{max} \sin \delta[/latex] . If the values of [latex] \delta \; and \; d\delta/dt [/latex] at the instant of fault clearing are 45[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] and 3.762 radian/s respectively, then  [latex]P_{max}[/latex] (in pu) is ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{2H}{\omega _s}\frac{d^2\delta }{dt^2}&=(P_m-P_e) \\ \text{Let, } \omega _r&=\frac{d\delta }{dt} \\ \frac{2H}{\omega _s}\frac{d\omega _r }{dt} &=(P_m-P_e) \\ \text{Multiplying with } &\omega _r \text{ in both side}\\ \frac{H}{\omega _s}\left ( 2\omega _r \frac{d\omega _r }{dt}\right )&= (P_m-P_e)\frac{d\delta }{dt}\\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{H}{\omega _s} 2d(\omega _r)^2&=(P_m-P_e)d\delta \\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{H}{\omega _s}\int_{\omega _{r_1}}^{\omega _{r_2}}d(\omega _r^2) &= \int_{\delta _1}^{\delta _2}(P_m-P_e)d\delta \\ \text{where, } & \\ \omega _{r_1}&=\left.\begin{matrix} \frac{d\delta }{dt} \end{matrix}\right|_{\delta =\delta _1} =\omega (\delta =\delta _1)-\omega _s\\ \omega _{r_2}&=\left.\begin{matrix} \frac{d\delta }{dt} \end{matrix}\right|_{\delta =\delta _2} =\omega (\delta =\delta _2)-\omega _s\\ \frac{H}{\omega _s}(\omega _{r_2}^2 -\omega _{r_1}^2)&=\int_{\delta _1}^{\delta _2}(P_m-P_e)d\delta \\ \text{In problem, }&\\ \frac{d\delta }{dt}=0, &\frac{d\delta }{dt}=3.762\\ \frac{5}{314}(3.762^2-0^2)&=\int_{30^{\circ}}^{45^{\circ}}(1-P_{max} \sin \delta )d\delta \\ \Rightarrow \;\; P_{max}&=0.23p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 89 The complex power consumed by a constant-voltage load is given by ([latex]P_1+jQ_1[/latex]), where,  [latex]1 kW \leq P1 \leq 1.5 kW[/latex]  and [latex]0.5 kVAR \leq Q_1 \leq 1 kVAR[/latex]. A compensating shunt capacitor is chosen such that  [latex]|Q| \leq 0.25 kVAR[/latex], where Q is the net reactive power consumed by the capacitor load combination. The reactive power (in kVAR) supplied by the capacitor is ____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given, }S_{load}&=P_1+jQ_1 \\ 1kW \leq P_1 &\leq1.5 kW \\ 0.5 \text{ kVAR} \leq Q_1 &\leq 1\text{ kVAR} \end{aligned}[/latex] Shunt capacitor will only supply reactive power and the total reactive power consumed by the load and the capacitor together will be less than 0.25 kVAR i.e.  [latex]Q \leq 0.25\text{ kVAR}[/latex] Therefore, reactive power supplied by the capacitor will be [latex]Q _C=(1-0.25)=0.75 \text{ kVAR (lagging)}[/latex]

question:
Question 90 For a 400 km long transmission line, the series impedance is [latex](0.0+j0.5)\Omega /km[/latex]
and the shunt admittance is[latex](0.0+j5.0)\mu mho /km[/latex]. The magnitude of the series
impedance (in [latex]\Omega[/latex] ) of the equivalent [latex]\pi[/latex] circuit of the transmission line is ____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} z &=(0+j0.5)\Omega /km \\ Z &=zl = (0+j200) \Omega\\ y&= (0+j5)\mu \Omega/km\\ Y&=yl=(0+j5) \times 10^{-6} \times 400\\ &=(0+j2 \times 10^{-3})\Omega \\ \gamma l &=\sqrt{ZY}=\sqrt{(200 \times 2 \times 10^{-3})} \\ \gamma l &= j0.6324 \\ &= \alpha l+j\beta l=0+j\beta l\\ Z_c&=\sqrt{\frac{Z}{Y}}=\sqrt{\frac{200}{2 \times 10^{-3}}} \\ &= 316.22\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex] Equivalent [latex]\pi[/latex]-network: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z &=Z_C \sin \gamma l \\ &= Z_C \sinh (\alpha l+j\beta l)\\ &=Z_C ( \sinh \alpha l\cdot \cos \beta l+j \cos \alpha l \sin \beta l) \\ &=316.22[\sin (0) \times \cos \beta l+j \cosh(0)] \\ & \sin \left ( 0.6324 \times \frac{180}{\pi} \right ) \\ &=187\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

obtain the load flow solution using Newton-Raphson method in polar coordinates,
the minimum number of simultaneous equations to be solved is _____.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} n&=183\\ &\text{No. of equations.}\\ &=2n-m-2\\ &=2 \times 183 -32-2=332 \end{aligned}[/latex] where, n= Total number of buses m= PV bus or reactive power support bus excluding slack bus One bus already has taken as slack bus.

question: Question 94 A three phase, 100 MVA, 25 kV generator has solidly grounded neutral. The positive, negative, and the zero sequence reactances of the generator are 0.2 pu, 0.2 pu and 0.05 pu, respectively, at the machine base quantities. If a bolted single phase to ground fault occurs at the terminal of the unloaded generator, the fault current in amperes immediately after the fault is_____.
solution: Given, [latex]X_1=0.2pu, X_2=0.2pu, X_3=0.05pu[/latex] For a line-to-ground fault on generator, fault current is given by [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{f_{LG}}&=3I_{R_0} =3I_{R_1}=3I_{R_2}\\ &= \frac{3E}{Z_1+Z_2+Z_3}\\ &=\frac{3 \times 1}{0.2+0.2+0.05} \\ &= \frac{3}{0.45}=\frac{20}{3}pu \end{aligned}[/latex] Also, base MVA =100 Base KVA =25 Theerefore, Base current, [latex]I_b=\frac{100 \times 10^6}{\sqrt{3} \times 25 \times 10^3}=2.309kA[/latex] Actual fault current in ampere [latex]=(I_{f_{LG}})_{pu} \times I_b=\frac{20}{30} \times 2.309 \times 10^3[/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;I_f=15393 \text{ Ampere}[/latex]

question: Question 95 The horizontally placed conductors of a single phase line operating at 50 Hz are having outside diameter of 1.6 cm, and the spacing between centers of the conductors is 6 m. The permittivity of free space is [latex]8.854 \times 10^{-12}[/latex] F/m. The capacitance to ground per kilometer of each line is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C &=\frac{2 \pi \in _0}{\ln \left ( \frac{d}{r} \right )} \\ &=\frac{2 \pi \in _0}{\ln \left ( \frac{2 \times 6}{1.6 \times 10^{-2}} \right )} \\ &= 8.4 \times 10^{-12} F/m\\ &= 8.4 \times 10^{-9} F/km \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 96 There are two generators in a power system. No-load frequencies of the generators are 51.5 Hz and 51 Hz, respectively, and both are having droop constant of 1Hz/MW. Total load in the system is 2.5 MW. Assuming that the generators are operating under their respective droop characteristics, the frequency of the power system in Hz in the steady state is ______.
solution: Let no-load frequency of generator-1 be 51.5 Hz and no-load frequency of generator-2 be 51 Hz. Given total load = 2.5 Mwand drop of both machines =1 Hz/MW Let machine-1 shares a load of [latex]P_1[/latex] MW them machine-2 will share a load of [latex](2.5-P_1)[/latex] MW Le the steady state frequency of the system be f. [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Now, }\frac{51.5-f}{P_1}&=1=droop \\ P_1&= (51.5-f)\;\;...(i)\\ \text{Also, } \left ( \frac{51-f}{2.5-P_1} \right )&=1=droop \\ 51-f &=2.5-P_1 \\ P_1 &=f-48.5 \;\;...(ii) \\ \text{equating eq. }&\text{(i) and (ii), we get,} \\ 51.5-f &=f-48.5 \\ 2f&=100 \\ f&=50Hz \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 97 A synchronous generator is connected to an infinite bus with excitation voltage [latex]E_f= 1.3[/latex] pu. The generator has a synchronous reactance of 1.1 pu and is delivering real power (P) of 0.6 pu to the bus. Assume the infinite bus voltage to be 1.0 pu. Neglect stator resistance. The reactive power (Q) in pu supplied by the generator to the bus under this condition is _____.
solution: Given, [latex]E_f=1.3pu, X_s=1.1pu, V=1 pu, P=0.6pu[/latex] Neglecting stator resistance i.e. [latex]\theta _s=90^{\circ}[/latex] Output power delivered, [latex]\begin{aligned} P &=\frac{VE_f}{X_s}\sin \delta \\ \sin \delta &=\frac{PX_s}{VE_f} \\ &= \frac{0.6 \times 1.1}{1 \times 1.3}\approx 0.5\\ \therefore \;\; \delta &=30^{\circ}=\text{Power angle} \\ \therefore \;\; \cos \delta &= \cos 30^{\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] Reactive power is given by, [latex]\begin{aligned} Q&=\left [ \frac{VE_f}{X_s} \cos \delta -\frac{V^2}{X_s} \right ]\\ &=\left [ \frac{1 \times 1.3}{1.1} \times \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{1^2}{1.1} \right ]\\ Q&=(1.023-0.909)=0.114pu\\ &\approx 0.11pu \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 98 Shunt reactors are sometimes used in high voltage transmission systems to
solution: Shunt reactor is basically an inductor having no-core or core is replaced by cement slab to avoid saturation problem. These are widely used to reduce the fault level or the short circuit current through the line.

options.A: limit the short circuit current through the line
options.B: compensate for the series reactance of the line under heavily loaded condition
options.C: limit over-voltages at the load side under lightly loaded condition.
options.D: compensate for the voltage drop in the line under heavily loaded condition.

question:
Question 99 A three phase star-connected load is drawing power at a voltage of 0.9 pu and 0.8
power factor lagging. The three phase base power and base current are 100 MVA
and 437.38 A respectively. The line-to-line load voltage in kV is _____.
solution: Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} V&=0.9pu, \cos \phi =0.8\\ S_{base}&=100MVA\\ I_{base}&=437.38A \end{aligned} [/latex] For a [latex]3-\phi[/latex] star connected systems, [latex]\begin{aligned} S_{base}&=\sqrt{3}(V_b)_{L-L}(I_b)_L\\ \therefore \; (V_b)_{L-L}&=\frac{S_{base}}{\sqrt{3} \times (I_b)_L}\\ &=\frac{100 \times 10^6}{\sqrt{3} \times (437.38)}=132kV \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;[/latex] Actual line to line load voltage in kV [latex]=0.9 \times 132kV=118.8kV[/latex]

question:
Question 100 The over current relays for the line protection and loads connected at the buses
are shown in the figure. The relays are IDMT in nature having the characteristic [latex]t_{op}=\frac{0.14\times Time \;  Multipller \; Setting}{(Plug \; Setting \; Multiplier)^{0.02}-1}[/latex] The maximum and minimum fault currents at bus B are 2000 A and 500 A
respectively. Assuming the time multiplier setting and plug setting for relay [latex]R_B[/latex]
to be 0.1 and 5 A respectively, the operating time of [latex]R_B[/latex] (in seconds) is_____.
solution: Minimum and maximum fault currents are [latex]I_{fmin}=500A, I_{fmax}=2000A[/latex] For relay [latex]R_B,\;TMS=0.1[/latex], plug setting =5A [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{PSM}&=\frac{I_f}{I_{pk} \times \text{C.T. ratio}} \\ \text{C.T. ratio} &=\frac{\text{Full load current}}{I_{pk}} \\ &= \frac{100}{5}\\ \text{At realy, }&R_B\\ \text{with }I_{fmin}\Rightarrow & \text{PSM}_1=\frac{500}{\frac{100}{5}\times 5}=5\\ \text{with }I_{fmax}\Rightarrow & \text{PSM}_2=\frac{2000}{\frac{100}{5}\times 5}=20 \end{aligned}[/latex] Operating time with TMS=0.1, and from IDMT characterisrics [latex]t_{op_2}=\frac{0.14 \times 0.1}{(20)^{0.02}-1}=0.226sec[/latex]

question:
Question 101 The fuel cost functions of two power plants are Plant [latex]P_1:C_1\equiv 0.05Pg^2_1+APg_1+B[/latex] Plant [latex]P_2:C_2\equiv 0.10Pg^2_2+3APg_2+2B[/latex] where, [latex]Pg_1 \; and \; Pg_2[/latex] are the generated powers of two plants, and A and B are the
constants. If the two plants optimally share 1000 MW load at incremental fuel
cost of 100 Rs/MWh, the ratio of load shared by plants [latex]P_1 \; and \; P_2[/latex] is
solution: Given, [latex]P_{g1}+P_{g2}=1000 \;\;...(i)[/latex] Also, incremental cost of production of [latex]g_1=\frac{dC_1}{dP_{g1}}=0.1P_{g1}+A \;\;\;...(ii)[/latex] and incremental cost of production of [latex]g_2=\frac{dC_2}{dP_{g2}}=0.2P_{g2}+3A\;\;\;...(iii)[/latex] For optimum load sharing [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dC_1}{dP_{g1}}&=\frac{dC_2}{dP_{g2}} \\ 0.1P_{g1}+A&=0.2P_{g2}+3A \\ 0.1P_{g1}-0.2P_{g2}&=2A \\ P_{g1}-2P_{g2}&=20A \;\;\;...(iv) \\ \text{Given, } \frac{dC_1}{dP_{g1}}&=\frac{dC_2}{dP_{g2}}=100\; Rs/MWh \end{aligned}[/latex] Putting this value in equation (ii), we have [latex]\begin{aligned} 100&=0.1P_{g1}+A\\ A&=(100-0.1P_{g1})\;\;...(v) \end{aligned}[/latex] Using equation (iv) and (v), we have: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{g1}-2P_{g2}&=20(100-0.1P_{g1})\\ 3P_{g1}-2P_{g2}&=20004\;\;...(vi) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{g1}&=800MW \text{ and } P_{g2}=200MW\\ \therefore \;P_{g1}:P_{g2}&=800:200=4:1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 102 A two bus power system shown in the figure supplies load of 1.0+j0.5 p.u. The values of [latex]V_1[/latex] in p.u. and [latex]\delta _2[/latex] respectively are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_2+jQ_2&=(1.0+j0.5)p.u.\\ P_2&=1=\frac{|V_1||V_2|}{|X|} \sin (\delta _1-\delta _2)\\ 1&=\frac{V_1}{0.1}\sin (-\delta _2)\\ -\frac{0.1}{\sin (-\delta _2)}&=V_1\;\;...(i)\\ Q_2&=0.5=\frac{|V_2|}{|X|}(|V_1| \cos \delta _2 -|V_2|)\\ 0.5&=\frac{1}{0.1}(V_1 \cos \delta _2-1)\\ \frac{1.05}{\cos \delta _2}&=V_1\;\;...(ii)\\ &\text{From equation (i) and (ii),}\\ \tan \delta _2&=\frac{-0.1}{1.05}\\ \delta _2&=-5.44^{\circ}\\ \text{substituting } & \delta _2 \text{ value in equation (ii) gives,}\\ V_1&=1.05\;p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 103 A distribution feeder of 1 km length having resistance, but negligible reactance, is fed from both the ends by 400 V, 50 Hz balanced sources. Both voltage sources [latex]S_1 \; and \; S_2[/latex] are in phase. The feeder supplies concentrated loads of unity power factor as shown in the figure. The contributions of [latex]S_1 \; and \; S_2[/latex] in 100 A current supplied at location P respectively, are
solution:
Let the resistance of whole length of feeder be [latex]R\;\Omega[/latex], length of feeder =1000m. [latex]\therefore \;[/latex] Resistance per unit length [latex]=\frac{R}{1000}\Omega /meter[/latex] [latex]\therefore \;[/latex] Resistance of 400 m length [latex]=\frac{R}{1000} \times 400 =\frac{2R}{5} \Omega [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;[/latex] Resistance of 200 m length [latex] =\frac{R}{5} \Omega [/latex] Let the current supplied by the sources be [latex]I_1 \text{ and } I_2[/latex]. Applying KVL from source [latex]S_1 \text{ and } S_2[/latex], we have: [latex]\begin{aligned}
400 &= \frac{2R}{5}I_1+\frac{R}{5}(I_1-200)\\ & -\frac{R}{5}(I_2-200)-\frac{R}{5}I_2+400\\ 
 0&= \frac{2}{5}I_1 +\frac{I_1-200}{5}+\frac{200-I_2}{5}-\frac{I_2}{5}\\ 
 0&=2I_1+I_1-200+200-I_2-I_2 \\ 
 0&=3I_1-2I_2\\
I_1&=\frac{2}{3}I_2\;\;\;...(i)\\
\text{also, }& I_1 +I_2-400=100\\
\text{or, }&I_1+I_2=500 \;\;\;...(ii)\\
&\text{Solvinf eq. (i) and (ii), we have}\\
I_1&=200A \text{ and }I_2=300A\\
&\text{Contribution of }S_1 \text{in 100 A at location}\\
P&=I_1-200=0A \\
&\text{Contribution of }S_2 \text{in 100 A at location}\\
P&=I_2-200=300-200=100A
\end{aligned}[/latex] Therefore, [latex]S_2[/latex] alone supplies the total load at location P.

question: Question 104 In an unbalanced three phase system, phase current [latex]I_a = 1\angle -90^{\circ}[/latex] pu, negative sequence current [latex]I_{b2}=4 \angle( -150^{\circ})[/latex], zero sequence current [latex]I_{c0}=3 \angle -90^{\circ}[/latex] pu. The magnitude of phase current [latex]I_{b}[/latex]  in pu is
solution:
Given, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_a&= 1\angle (-90^{\circ})pu\\ I_b&= 4\angle (-150^{\circ})pu\\ I_c&= 3\angle (90^{\circ})pu \end{aligned}[/latex] As zero sequence current in all the three phases of unbalanced [latex]3-\phi[/latex] system are equal, therefore, [latex]I_{a_0}=I_{b_0}=I_{c_0}=3\angle 90^{\circ}pu[/latex] Also,  [latex]I_{b_2}=4\angle -150^{\circ}[/latex] =Negative phase sequence current of phase b. Therefore, referring to the negative phase sequence phasor, [latex]I_{b_2}=4\angle (-150^{\circ}-120^{\circ})=4\angle-270^{\circ}pu[/latex] We know that, phase current vectors in matrix form are given by [latex] \begin{aligned}
\begin{bmatrix}
I_a\\ 
I_b\\ 
I_c
\end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix}
1 &1  &1 \\ 
 1& a^2 &a \\ 
1 & a &a^2 
\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}
I_{a_0}\\ 
I_{a_1}\\ 
I_{a_2}
\end{bmatrix} \\ 
\text{Here, } I_a&=I_{a_0}+I_{a_1}+I_{a_2} \\ 
\text{Given, } I_a&=1\angle -90^{\circ} \\ 
 I_{a_0}&=3\angle 90^{\circ} \\ 
 I_{a_2}&=4\angle -270^{\circ} \\ 
 \text{Therefore,}& \\ 
 I_{a_1}&=I_a-(I_{a_0}+I_{a_2}) \\ 
 &=(1\angle -90^{\circ})-(3\angle 90^{\circ}+4\angle 270^{\circ}) \\ 
 I_{a_1}&=8\angle -90^{\circ}pu \\ 
 \text{Therefore,}& \\
 I_b&=I_{a_0}+a^2I_{a_1}+aI_{a_2}\\
&=(3\angle 90^{\circ})+(1\angle 120^{\circ})^2 (8\angle -90^{\circ}) \\
&+(1\angle 120^{\circ})(4\angle -270^{\circ})\\
&=3\angle 90^{\circ}+8\angle 150^{\circ}+4\angle -150^{\circ}\\
I_b&=11.53\angle 154.3^{\circ}pu\\
&\text{Magnitude of phase current,}\\
I_b&=11.53\;pu
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 105 A 2-bus system and corresponding zero sequence network are shown in the figure. The transformers T1 and T2 are connected as
solution: We have to use switch diagram for the zero-sequence network of transformer. Switch 1 or 2 is closed when winding in Yand neutral grounded. Therefore, transformer will be connected in primary with grounded neutral and secondary in star with isolated neutral. For transformer [latex]T_2[/latex], switch 1 is closed and 2 is closed, therefore, primary winding is star connected with neutral grounded whereas secondary will be delta connected.

question:

are very small, and the line resistances are negligible. All the line reactances are equal to [latex]j1 \Omega[/latex]. The voltage phase angles in rad at buses 2 and 3 are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_1+P_2+P_3&=0 \\ P_1+j0.1-j0.2&=0 \\ P_1&= j0.1\; p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex] No power flow in between bus 1 and 2. reference node, the current drawn by the capacitor per unit is
solution: Thevenin's equivalent circuit between bus (3) and reference bus [latex]=Z_{33}=j0.5[/latex] Thevenin's equivalent circuit between 3rd bus (3) and reference [latex]V_{Th}=1.3\angle -10^{\circ}p.u.[/latex] [latex]I_{C}=\frac{1.3\angle -10}{j0.5-j3.5}=0.433\angle 80^{\circ}p.u.[/latex]

question:
Question 112 A cylinder rotor generator delivers 0.5 pu power in the steady-state to an infinite
bus through a transmission line of reactance 0.5 pu. The generator no-load voltage
is 1.5 pu and the infinite bus voltage is 1 pu. The inertia constant of the generator
is 5MW-s/MVA and the generator reactance is 1 pu. The critical clearing angle,
in degrees, for a three-phase dead short circuit fault at the generator terminal is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_e&= \frac{|E||V|}{(X_d+X_T)}\sin \delta _0\\ 0.5 &=\frac{1.5 \times 1}{(1+0.5)}\sin \delta _0 \\ \delta _0 &=\sin ^{-1}(0.5)=30^{\circ}=\frac{\pi}{6} \end{aligned}[/latex] Critical clearing angle [latex]\begin{aligned} \delta _{cr}&=\cos ^{-1}[(\pi-2\delta _0) \sin \delta _0 -\cos \delta _0]\\ &=\cos ^{-1}\left [ \left ( \pi-\frac{\pi}{3} \right ) \times \frac{1}{2} -\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right ]\\ &= \cos ^{-1} (0.18)=79.56^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 113 For the system below, [latex]S_{D1} \; and \; S_{D2}[/latex] are complex power demands at bus 1 and bus
2 respectively. If [latex]|V_2|=1[/latex] pu, the VAR rating of the capacitor ([latex]Q_{G2}[/latex]) connected at
bus 2 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text{Real power,} \\ P_r&= \frac{|V_S||V_R|}{|X} \sin \delta \\ 1 &=\frac{1.0 \times 1.0}{0.5}\sin \delta \\ \delta &= \sin^{-1} (0.5)=30^{\circ}\\ &\text{Reactive power,} \\ Q_r&= \frac{|V_S||V_R|}{|X} \cos \delta -\frac{|V|^2}{|X|}\\ &= \frac{1.0 \times 1.0}{0.5}\cos 30-\frac{1^2}{0.5} \\ &= \frac{\left ( \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right )}{\frac{1}{2}}-2\\ &= 1.732-2=-0.268\\ \text{But, } & Q_r+Q_C=0\\ Q_C&=-Q_r=0.268\;p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 115 The figure shows a two-generator system applying a load of [latex]P_D[/latex]= 40MW,
connected at bus 2. The fuel cost of generators G1 and G2 are : [latex]C_1(P_{G1})[/latex]=10,000 Rs/MWh and [latex]C_2(P_{G2})[/latex]=12,500 Rs/MWh
and the loss in the line is [latex]P_{loass(pu)}=0.5P_{G1(pu)}^2[/latex], where the loss coefficient is specified in pu on a
100 MVA base. The most economic power generation schedule in MW is
solution: From cordination equation [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dF_n}{dP_{Gn}}\cdot \frac{1}{1-\frac{\partial P_L}{\partial P_{Gn}}}&=\lambda \\ \text{Given: }P_L&=0.5P_{G1}^2\\ \frac{\partial P_L}{\partial P_{G1}}=P_{G1} \text{ and } \frac{\partial P_L}{\partial P_{G2}}&= 0\\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{dF_{1}}{dP_{G1}}\frac{1}{1-P_{G1}}&=\frac{dF_2}{dP_{G2}}\frac{1}{1-0}\\ \Rightarrow \; 10000 \times \frac{1}{1-P_{G1}}&=12500\\ 1-P_{G1}=\frac{100}{125}&=\frac{4}{5}\\ P_{G1}&=\frac{1}{5}p.u.\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] as the base value is 100 MVA [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{G1}&=\frac{1}{5} \times 100=20MW\\ \Rightarrow \; P_L&=0.5P_{G1}^2\\ &=0.5\left ( \frac{1}{5} \right )^2=0.02p.u.\\ \Rightarrow \; P_L&=0.02 \times 100=2MW\\ P_D&=P_{G1}+P_{G2}-P_L\\ 40&=20+P_{G2}-2\\ \Rightarrow \;\;P_{G2}&=22 MV \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 116 The bus admittance matrix of a three-bus three-line system is [latex]Y=j\begin{bmatrix} -13 & 10 & 5\\ 10& -18 & 10\\ 5 & 10 & -13 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] If each transmission line between the two buses is represented by an equivalent [latex]\pi[/latex]-network, the magnitude of the shunt susceptance of the line connecting bus 1 and 2 is
solution: [latex]y_{ik}=[/latex] Series admittance of the line connecting buses I and k [latex]\frac{y_{ik}'}{2}=[/latex] Half line charging admittance in bus admittance matrix [latex]\begin{aligned} Y_{11}&=\frac{y_{12}'}{2} +\frac{y_{31}'}{2} +y_{12}+y_{31}=-j13\\ y_{12} &=-y_{12}=j10 \\ y_{23} &=-y_{23}=j10 \\ y_{31} &=-y_{31}=j5 \\ \therefore \; Y_{12}'+y_{31}'&=2[-j13+j10+j5] \\ &= j4\\ &\text{similarly,} \\ y_{12}'+y_{23}' &=2[-j18+j10+j10]=j4 \\ y_{23}'+y_{31}' &=2[-j13+j10+j5]=j4 \\ \rightarrow \;\; y_{12}' &=j6-j4=j2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

mid-point as shown below G1 = 250 MVA, 15kV, positive sequence reactance X = 25% on its own base G2 = 100 MVA, 15kV, positive sequence reactance X = 10 % on its own base [latex]L_1 \; and \;  L_2[/latex]=10km, positive sequence reactance X = 0.225 [latex]\Omega[/latex]/km In the above system, the three-phase fault MVA at the bus 3 is

question:
Question 118 Two generator units G1 and G2 are connected by 15 kV line with a bus at the
mid-point as shown below G1 = 250 MVA, 15kV, positive sequence reactance X = 25% on its own base G2 = 100 MVA, 15kV, positive sequence reactance X = 10 % on its own base [latex]L_1 \; and \;  L_2[/latex]=10km, positive sequence reactance X = 0.225 [latex]\Omega[/latex]/km For the above system, the positive sequence diagram with the p.u. values on the 100 MVA common base is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{New MVA Base} &=(MVA_B)_{new}=100MVA \\ Z_{p.u.(new)}&=Z_{p.u.(old)} \times \frac{(MVA_B)_{new}}{(MVA_B)_{old}} \times \frac{(kV_B)^2_{old}}{(kV_B)^2_{new}}\\ (kV_B)_{old} &=(kV_B)_{new} =15kV\\ &\text{On 100 MVA and 15 kV base,} \\ X_{G2} &=0.1\; p.u. \\ X_{G1}&=0.25 \times \frac{100}{250}=0.1 \; p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex] Positive sequence reactance of [latex]L_1 \text{ and }L_2 =X_L=0.225 \times 10=2.25\Omega[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Base impedance} &=Z_B =\frac{(kV_B)^2_{new}}{(MVA_B)_{new}}\\ &= \frac{15^2}{100}=2.25\Omega \\ X_L(\text{in pu}) &=\frac{2.25}{2.25}=1 \; p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex] Hence, option (A) is correct.

Question 120 A load center of 120 MW derives power from two power stations connected by
220 kV transmission lines of 25 km and 75 km as shown in the figure below. The
three generators G1, G2 and G3 are of 100 MW capacity each and have identical

solution: Let load center is connected at point x If r is resistance/km of line Resistance of section between 1 nad x [latex]R_1=r \times 25=R[/latex] Resistance of section between x nad 2 [latex]R_2=r \times 75=3R[/latex] Current (I) fed by generator [latex]\propto[/latex] power produced by the generator. [latex]I_1 \propto P_1, I_2 \propto P_2 \text{ and }I_3\propto P_3[/latex] Transmission losses [latex]\begin{aligned} P_L&=I_1^2 R+I_2^2 3R+ I_3^23R \\ P_L&\propto (P_1^2+3P_2^2+3P_3^2) \\ P_L&=K[P_1^2+3P_2^2+3P_3^2] \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text{Option (A)}\\ P_1&=80MW\\ P_2&=20MW\\ P_3&=20MW\\ P_L&=K[80^2+3 \times 20^2+3 \times 20^2]\\ &=8800KMW \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text{Option (B)}\\ P_1&=60MW\\ P_2&=30MW\\ P_3&=30MW\\ P_L&=K[60^2+3 \times 30^2+3 \times 30^2]\\ &=9000KMW \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text{Option (C)}\\ P_1&=40MW\\ P_2&=40MW\\ P_3&=40MW\\ P_L&=K[40^2+3 \times 40^2+3 \times 40^2]\\ &=11200KMW \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &\text{Option (D)}\\ P_1&=30MW\\ P_2&=45MW\\ P_3&=45MW\\ P_L&=K[30^2+3 \times 45^2+3 \times 45^2]\\ &=13050 KMW \end{aligned}[/latex] So, option (A) gives minimum losses.

Question 125 Consider a three-core, three-phase, 50 Hz, 11 kV cable whose conductors are
denoted as R,Y and B in the figure. The inter-phase capacitance(C1) between each pair of conductors is 0.2 [latex]\mu[/latex]F and the capacitance between
each line conductor and the sheath is 0.4 [latex]\mu[/latex]F . The per-phase charging current is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z'&=Z/3\\ \frac{1}{\omega C'}&=\frac{1}{3\omega C}\\ C'&=3C \end{aligned}[/latex] Equivalent capacitance ([latex]C_{eq}[/latex]) between a phase and ground [latex]\begin{aligned} C_{eq} &=C'+C_2=3C_1+C_2\\ C_{eq} &= 3 \times 0.2+0.4=1\mu F\\ &\text{Per phase voltage,}\\ V_P&=\frac{11}{\sqrt{3}}kV\\ &\text{Per phase charging current}\\ I&=j\omega C_{eq}V_P\\ |I_C|&=\omega C_{eq}V_P\\ &=2 \pi \times 50 \times 1 \times 1 \times 10^{-6}\\ & \times \frac{11}{\sqrt{3}} \times 10^3\\ &\approx 2A \end{aligned}[/latex]

is suspended by an insulator string having two identical porcelain insulators. The
self capacitance of the insulator is 5 times the shunt capacitance between the link and the ground, as shown in the figures. The voltages across the two insulators are
solution: Line to line voltage [latex]=V_{l-l}=11kV[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} V_P&=\text{Phase to ground voltage} \\ V_P&=\frac{V_{l-l}}{\sqrt{3}}=\frac{11}{\sqrt{3}}kV \\ e_1+e_2&= \frac{11}{\sqrt{3}}kV=6.35kV \;\;...(i)\\ I&=I_1+I_2 \\ (j\omega 5C) \times e_1 &= (j\omega C) \times e_2 +(j\omega 5C) \times C_2 \;\;..(ii)\\ 5e_1&=6e_2\\ \text{Solving } & \text{equation (i) and (ii), we get,} \\ e_1&=3.46kV\\ e_2&=2.89kV \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 127 A 50 Hz synchronous generator is initially connected to a long lossless transmission line which is open circuited at the receiving end. With the field voltage held constant, the generator is disconnected from the transmission line. Which of the following may be said about the steady state terminal voltage and field current of the generator ?
solution: As field voltage is held constant, so field current does not change. When the generator is connected with open-circuit transmission line, line draws charging current. Therefore, [latex]V_t[/latex] is higher than [latex]E_g[/latex]  i.e. [latex]V_t \gt E_g[/latex] But when the generator is disconnected from the line, no charging current is delivered by the generator i.e. [latex]I_C=0[/latex]. In this [latex]V_t=E_g[/latex] So, terminal voltage decreases.

options.A: The magnitude of terminal voltage decreases, and the field current does not change.
options.B: The magnitude of terminal voltage increases, and the field current does not change.
options.C: The magnitude of terminal voltage increases, and the field current increases
options.D:
The magnitude of terminal voltage does not change and the field current
decreases.

question: Question 128 The zero-sequence circuit of the three phase transformer shown in the figure
solution: Equivalent circuit for the zero sequence network depends upon the impedances met by the zero sequence currents flowing through the three phases and their sum, [latex]3I_{a0}[/latex], flowing through the neutral impedance and returning through the ground or a neutral conductor. If there is no complete path for zero sequence currents in a circuit, the zero sequence impedance is infinite. Thus a Y-connected circuit with ungrounded neutral has infinite impedance to zero sequence currents. A delta-connected circuit provides no path for zero sequence currents flowing in the line. The zero sequence currents being single phase, circulate within the winding. Hence viewed from its terminals its zero sequence impedance is infinite.

Question 131 Consider two buses connected by an impedence of [latex](0+j5)\Omega[/latex]. The bus 1 voltage
is 100[latex]\angle 30^{\circ}[/latex] V, and bus 2 voltage is 100[latex]\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex] V. The real and reactive power supplied by bus 1 respectively are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_1&=100\angle 30^{\circ}V\\ V_2&=100\angle 0^{\circ}V \end{aligned}[/latex] as [latex]\delta _1 \gt \delta _2[/latex], current will flow from bus 1 to bus 2 [latex]\begin{aligned} Z&=0+j5\Omega \\ I&=\frac{V_1-V_2}{Z}\\ &=\frac{100\angle 30^{\circ}-100\angle 0^{\circ}}{j5}\\ &=10.35\angle 15^{\circ}A\\ &\text{Complex power, }\\ &=S=P+j\theta =V_1I^*\\ P+jQ&=100\angle 30^{\circ} \times (10.35\angle 15^{\circ})\\ &\approx 1000+j268\\ P&=1000W \text{ and }Q=268 \text{ VAR} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 142 Consider a power system shown below: Given that:[latex]V_{s1}=V_{s2}=1+j0[/latex] p.u; The positive sequence impedance are [latex]Z_{s1}=Z_{s2}=0.001+j0.01[/latex] p.u and [latex]Z_{L}=0.006+j0.06[/latex] p.u 3-phase Base MVA = 100 voltage base = 400 kV(Line to Line) Nominal system frequency= 50 Hz. time '[latex]t_0[/latex]'. The positive sequence impedance from source S1 to point 'F' equals 0.004+j0.04  p.u. The wave form corresponding to phase 'a' fault current from

solution: Fault occurs at mid point 'F' Thevenins equivalent, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_s &=V_{s_1} =V_{s_2}=1.0\angle 0\;pu\\ Z_1&= \left ( Z_{s_1}+\frac{Z_L}{2} \right )||\left ( Z_{s_2}+\frac{Z_L}{2} \right )\\ \text{as } Z_{s_1}&=Z_{s_2} =0.001+j0.1 \; pu\\ \text{and } Z_L&=0.006+j0.06 \\ Z_1 &=\frac{1}{2}\left ( Z_{s_1}+\frac{Z_L}{2} \right ) \\ &= \frac{1}{2}\left ( 0.001+j0.01+\frac{0.006+j0.06}{2} \right )\\ Z_1&=0.002+j0.02 \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Fault current}&=I_f=\frac{V_s}{Z_1}=\frac{1\angle 0^{\circ}}{0.002+j0.02}\\ &=49.75\angle -84.29 \; p.u.\\ |I_f|p.u.&=49.75\\ \text{Base current}&=\frac{\text{Base MVA}}{\sqrt{3} \times \text{Voltage Base}}kA\\ I_B&=\frac{100}{\sqrt{3} \times 400}kA\\ |I_f|&=|I_f|_{p.u.} \times I_B\\ &=49.75 \times \frac{100}{\sqrt{3} \times 400}\\ &=7.18 kA\\ I_x^f&=\frac{|I_f|}{2}=\frac{7.18}{2}kA=3.59kA \end{aligned}[/latex]

to postive sequence impedance and the zero sequence impedances are three times
positive sequence impedances. The instant ([latex]t_0[/latex]) of the fault will be
solution: To find [latex]i(t)[/latex] and [latex]t(0^+)[/latex] we can convert the above circuit in following way [latex]\text{Let, } t'=t-t_0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; t=t'+t_0[/latex] [latex]i(t')=\frac{\sqrt{2}V}{|z|}\cos (\omega t'+\omega t_0-\alpha )+Ae^{-\frac{t}{\tau }}\;\;(t'\geq t_0^+)[/latex] Symmetrical short circuit current, [latex]\begin{aligned} |Z|&= \sqrt{R^2+(\omega L)^2}\\ \alpha &= \tan^{-1} \frac{\omega L}{R}\\ \tau &=\frac{L}{R} \\ \text{Now, } &i(t'=0^-) =i(t'=0^+)=0 \\ \Rightarrow \; \frac{\sqrt{2}V}{|Z|} & \cos (\omega t_0-\alpha )+A=0 \\ A&=-\frac{\sqrt{2}V}{|Z|}\cos (\omega t_0-\alpha) \\ &\text{Now change, } \\ t'&=t-t_0 \\ i(t) &=-\frac{\sqrt{2}V}{|Z|}\cos (\omega t-\alpha) \\ &-\frac{\sqrt{2}V}{|Z|}\cos (\omega t_0-\alpha)e^{-\frac{(t-t_0)R}{L}}\;\; t \geqt_0^+ \end{aligned}[/latex] Now, if the initial value of dc of set (A) is [latex]-\frac{\sqrt{2}V}{|Z|}[/latex] it requires that [latex]\cos (\omega t_0-\alpha)=1[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; \omega t_0-\alpha =0[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; t_0=\frac{\alpha }{\omega }=\frac{\tan^{-1} \frac{\omega L}{R}}{\omega }[/latex] In problem given the circuit for [latex]3-\phi[/latex] fault be drawn as: According to the derrivation For initial value of dc off set to be [latex]-\frac{\sqrt{2}V}{|Z|}[/latex] we required [latex]t_0=\frac{\tan^{-1} \frac{\omega L}{R}}{\omega }=\frac{\tan^{-1} \frac{0.04}{0.004}}{2 \times 3.14 \times 50 }=4.68msec[/latex]

question:
Question 144 Single line diagram of a 4-bus single source distribution system is shown below.
Branches [latex]e_1,e_2,e_3 \; and \; e_4[/latex] have equal impedances. The load current values indicated in the figure are in per unit. Distribution company's policy requires radial system operation with minimum
loss. This can be achieved by opening of the branch
solution: Assuming impedance of each branch R (i) if [latex]e_1[/latex] is opened Total losses [latex]=8^2R+3^2R+1^2R=74R[/latex] (ii) if [latex]e_2[/latex] is opened Total losses [latex]=8^2R+7^2R+5^2R=138R[/latex] (i) if [latex]e_3[/latex] is opened Total losses [latex]=1^2R+7^2R+2^2R=54R[/latex] (i) if [latex]e_4[/latex] is opened Total losses [latex]=5^2R+3^2R+1^2R=38R[/latex] Operation with minimum loss can be achieved by opening line [latex]e_4[/latex].

question: Question 145 A loss less single machine infinite bus power system is shown below : The synchronous generator transfers 1.0 per unit of power to the infinite bus. The critical clearing time of circuit breaker is 0.28 s. If another identical synchronous generator is connected in parallel to the existing generator and each generator is scheduled to supply 0.5 per unit of power, then the critical clearing time of the circuit breaker will
solution: For such faults, [latex]\delta _{cr}[/latex] is given by [latex]\delta _{cr}=\cos ^{-1} [(\pi-2\delta _0) \sin \delta _0 -\cos \delta _0]\;...(i)[/latex] and [latex]\begin{aligned} t_{cr}&=\text{critical cleaning time } \\ &= \left ( \frac{2H(\delta _{cr}-\delta _0)}{\pi f P_m} \right )^{1/2}\;...(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] CASE-1: When only once generator is connected Mechanical input to the generator [latex](P_{m_1})=[/latex] Electrical power delivered by the generator [latex](P_{e_1})[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; P_{m_1}=P_{e_1}=1p.u.[/latex] CASE-2: When two generator connected in parallel Electrical power delivered by each generator [latex]P_{e_2}=0.5p.u.[/latex] Mechanical inout to each generator [latex](P_{m_2})=P_{e_2}=0.5p.u.=\frac{P_{m_1}}{2}[/latex] Assuming [latex]\delta _0[/latex] in each case same [latex]\delta _{0_1}=\delta _{0_2}=\delta _{0}[/latex] So, [latex]\delta _{cr}[/latex]  will also be same in both cases, (from equation (i)), [latex]\begin{aligned} t_{cr}&\propto \frac{1}{\sqrt{P_m}}\\ &(\delta _{cr}, H \text{ and } \delta _0 \text{ are same}) \\ \therefore \; t_{cr_2} &=\sqrt{\frac{P_{m_1}}{P_{m_2}}}\times t_{cr_1} \\ t_{cr_2}&= \sqrt{\frac{P_{m_1}}{P_{m_1}/2}}\times 0.28\\ &= \sqrt{2} \times 0.28=0.396\;sec \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.B: reduce but will be more than 0.14 s

question:
Question 146 A loss less power system has to serve a load of 250 MW. There are tow generation
(G1 and G2) in the system with cost curves [latex]C_1 \; and \; C_2[/latex] respectively defined as
follows: [latex]C_{1}(P_{G1})=P_{G1}+0.055\times P^{2}_{G1} [/latex] [latex]C_{2}(P_{G1})=3 P_{G2}+0.03 \times P^{2}_{G2}[/latex] where [latex]P_{G1} \; and \; P_{G2}[/latex] are the MW injections from generator G1 and G2 respectively.
Thus, the minimum cost dispatch will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} C_1(P_{G1})&=P_{G1}+0.055P_{G1}^2\\ \frac{dC_1}{P_{G1}}&=1+0.11P_{G1}\\ C_2(P_{G2})&=P_{G2}+0.03P_{G2}^2\\ \frac{dC_2}{P_{G2}}&=3+0.06P_{G2} \end{aligned}[/latex] For minimum cost analysis [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dC_1}{P_{G1}}&=\frac{dC_2}{P_{G2}}\\ 1+0.11P_{G1}&=3+0.06P_{G2}\;\;...(i)\\ P_{G1}+P_{G2}&=250MW\;\;...(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving equation (i) and (ii), we get,  [latex]P_{G1}=100MW[/latex] and [latex]P_{G2}=150MW[/latex]

question:
Question 147 A loss less transmission line having Surge Impedance Loading (SIL) of 2280 MW
is provided with a uniformly distributed series capacitive compensation of 30%.
Then, SIL of the compensated transmission line will be
solution: Surge impedance loading= SIL =2280 MW [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_c&= \text{Surge impedance}\\ \text{SIL}_{2}&=\frac{\text{SIL}_{1}}{\sqrt{1-\gamma _{se}}}\\ \text{SIL}_{2}&=\frac{2280}{\sqrt{1-0.3}}\\ &=2725.12 \text{ MW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:

a magnitude of 1.0 per unit but are 180 degree out of phase. Assuming that the

Directional over current protection set to pick up at 1.25 times the
