question:
Question 149 A-3-phase transmission line is shown in figure : Voltage drop across the transmission line is given by the following equation : [latex]\begin{bmatrix} \Delta V_{a}\\ \Delta V_{b}\\ \Delta V_{c} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} Z_{s} & Z_{m} & Z_{m}\\ Z_{m} & Z_{s}&Z_{m} \\ Z_{m} & Z_{m} & Z_{s} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} I_{a}\\ I_{b}\\ I_{c} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] Shunt capacitance of the line can be neglect. If the has positive sequence impedance
of 15 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and zero sequence impedance of 48 [latex]\Omega[/latex], then the values of [latex]Z_s \; and \; Z_m[/latex] will be
solution: Positive sequence impedance = Negative sequence impedance [latex]=Z_s-Z_m=15 \;\;...(i)[/latex] Zero-sequence impedance [latex]=Z_s+2Z_m=48\;\;...(ii)[/latex] Solving equation (i) and (ii), we get, [latex]Z_s=26\Omega[/latex] and [latex]Z_m=11\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 150 An extra high voltage transmission line of length 300 km can be approximate by
a lossless line having propagation constant [latex]\beta[/latex] = 0.00127 radians per km. Then the percentage ratio of line length to wavelength will be given by
solution: Wave length [latex]=\lambda[/latex], Propogation constant [latex]=\beta[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \lambda &= \frac{2 \pi}{\beta }=\frac{2 \pi}{0.00127}\\ &= 4947.39km\\ \text{Ratio} &=\frac{\text{ Line length}}{wave length} \\ &= \frac{300 km}{4947.39km}\\ &=0.0606\\ \% \text{Ratio}&=6.06\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 151 A two machine power system is shown below. The Transmission line XY has
positive sequence impedance of [latex]Z_{1}\Omega[/latex] and zero sequence impedance of [latex]Z_{0}\Omega[/latex] An 'a' phase to ground fault with zero fault impedance occurs at the centre of the
transmission line. Bus voltage at X and line current from X to F for the phase
'a', are given by [latex]V_a[/latex] Volts and [latex]I_a[/latex] amperes, respectively. Then, the impedance
measured by the ground distance relay located at the terminal X of line XY will
be given by
solution: As the ground distance relay is located at terminals x Impedance measured by the relay [latex]=\frac{\text{Bus voltage}}{\text{current}}=\frac{V_a}{I_a}[/latex]

question:
Question 152 An isolated 50 Hz synchronous generator is rated at 15 MW which is also the
maximum continuous power limit of its prime mover. It is equipped with a speed
governor with 5% droop. Initially, the generator is feeding three loads of 4 MW
each at 50 Hz. One of these loads is programmed to trip permanently if the
frequency falls below 48 Hz .If an additional load of 3.5 MW is connected then
the frequency will settle down to
solution: Here, change in (frequency) w.r.t. to power [latex]\begin{aligned} \left ( \frac{5}{15} \right ) \times 3.5&=1.16\%\\ \therefore \; \Delta f &=0.583\\ \therefore \; f&=50-0.583\\ &=49.417 Hz \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 153 A 230 V (Phase), 50 Hz, three-phase, 4-wire, system has a phase sequence ABC.
A unity power-factor load of 4 kW is connected between phase A and neutral N.
It is desired to achieve zero neutral current through the use of a pure inductor
and a pure capacitor in the other two phases. The value of inductor and capacitor
is
solution: Taking [latex]V_{AN}[/latex] as the reference [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{AN}&=230\angle 0^{\circ} V\\ V_{BN}&=230\angle -120^{\circ}V \\ V_{CN}&=230\angle 120^{\circ}V \\ I_A&= \frac{P}{V_{AN} \cos \phi }\\ &= \frac{4 \times 10^3}{230 \times 1}\\ &=17.4\angle 0^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] If an pure inductor is present in phase B, then [latex]I_B[/latex] lags [latex]V_{BN}[/latex] by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]. If a pure capacitor is present in phase C, then [latex]I_C[/latex] leads [latex]V_{CN}[/latex] by [latex]90^{\circ}[/latex]. If current through neutral is to be zero. [latex]\begin{aligned} I_B \sin 30^{\circ} &=I_C \sin 30^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \; I_B &=I_C=I \\ I_A&=I_B \cos 30^{\circ} +I_C \cos 30^{\circ} \\ &=2I \cos 30^{\circ}=\sqrt{3}I \\ |I_B|&=|I_C|=|I|=\frac{|I_A|}{\sqrt{3}} \\ &= \frac{17.04}{\sqrt{3}}=10.05\\ |I_B|&=\frac{|V_{BN}|}{\omega L} \\ 10.05 &=\frac{230}{2 \pi \times 50 \times L} \\ L&=72.847 mH \\ |I_C| &=|V_{CN}| \cdot \omega C\\ 10.05&=230 \times 2 \times \pi \times 50 \times C \\ C&=139.087 \mu F \end{aligned}[/latex]

options.A: 72.95 mH in phase C and 139.02 [latex]\mu[/latex]F in Phase B
options.B: 72.95 mH in Phase B and 139.02 [latex]\mu[/latex]F in Phase C
options.C: 42.12 mH in Phase C and 240.79 [latex]\mu[/latex]F in Phase B
options.D: 42.12 mH in Phase B and 240.79 [latex]\mu[/latex]F in Phase C

question:
Question 154 Consider the two power systems shown in figure A below, which are initially not
interconnected, and are operating in steady state at the same frequency. Separate load flow solutions are computed individually of the two systems, corresponding to this scenario. The bus voltage phasors so obtain are indicated on figure A. These two isolated systems are now interconnected by a short transmission line as shown in figure B, and it is found that [latex]P_1=P_2=Q_1=Q_2=0[/latex]. The bus voltage phase angular difference between generator bus X and generator
bus Y after interconnection is
solution: Flow of power in transmission line depends on bus voltage magnitude and phase difference between bus voltage. After interconnecting the two system by a line there is no power flow in the line hence bus voltage magnitude and phase difference between buses will remain same as before interconnecting the two systems. Phase difference between bus X and bus Y [latex]=30-20=10^{\circ}[/latex]

question:
Question 155 Suppose we define a sequence transformation between "a-b-c" and "p-n-o"
variables as follows: [latex]\begin{bmatrix} f_{a}\\ f_{b}\\ f_{c} \end{bmatrix}=k\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1\\ \alpha ^{2}&\alpha & 1\\ \alpha & \alpha ^{2} & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} f_{p}\\ f_{n}\\ f_{o} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] where [latex]\alpha =e^{j\frac{2\pi }{3}}[/latex] and k and is a constant. Now, if it is given that : [latex]\begin{bmatrix} V_{p}\\ V_{n}\\ V_{o} \end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix} 0.5 & 0&0 \\ 0 & 0.5 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 2.0 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} i_{p}\\ i_{n}\\ i_{o} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] and [latex] \begin{bmatrix} V_{a}\\ V_{b}\\ V_{c} \end{bmatrix}=Z\begin{bmatrix} i_{a}\\ i_{b}\\ i_{c} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] then,
solution: Here, [latex]\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} V_p\\ V_n\\ V_0 \end{bmatrix}&=\begin{bmatrix} 0.5 & 0 & 0\\ 0& 0.5 &0 \\ 0&0 &2 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} I_p\\ I_n\\ I_o \end{bmatrix}\\ \text{where, } \begin{bmatrix} V_a\\ V_b\\ V_c \end{bmatrix}&=[Z]\begin{bmatrix} I_a\\ I_b\\ I_c \end{bmatrix}\;\;...(i)\\ \begin{bmatrix} I_a\\ I_b\\ I_c \end{bmatrix}&=K\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1\\ \alpha ^2 &\alpha &1 \\ \alpha & \alpha ^2& 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} I_p\\ I_n\\ I_o \end{bmatrix}\\ &=KA\begin{bmatrix} I_p\\ I_n\\ I_o \end{bmatrix}\\ \text{similarly, }V_{ph}&=k[A]V_{sequence}\\ &=K[A]\begin{bmatrix} 0.5 &0 & 0\\ 0 & 0.5& 0\\ 0& 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}[I_{sequence}]\\ &=K[A]\begin{bmatrix} 0.5 &0 & 0\\ 0 & 0.5& 0\\ 0& 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\frac{[A^{-1}]}{K}I_{ph}\;\;...(ii)\\ &\text{comparing eq. (i) with (ii),}\\ \therefore \; Z&=A\begin{bmatrix} 0.5 &0 & 0\\ 0 & 0.5& 0\\ 0& 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}[A^{-1}]\\ &=\frac{1}{3}\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1\\ \alpha ^2 &\alpha &1 \\ \alpha & \alpha ^2& 1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 0.5 &0 & 0\\ 0 & 0.5& 0\\ 0& 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1 & \alpha & \alpha ^2\\ 1 &\alpha ^2 & \alpha \\ 1 & 1& 1 \end{bmatrix}\\ &=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0.5 & 0.5\\ 0.5 & 1& 0.5\\ 0.5& 0.5 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 156 Consider a synchronous generator connected to an infinite bus by two identical
parallel transmission line. The transient reactance 'x' of the generator is 0.1 pu
and the mechanical power input to it is constant at 1.0 pu. Due to some previous
disturbance, the rotor angle ([latex]\delta[/latex]) is undergoing an undamped oscillation, with the maximum value of [latex]\delta (t)[/latex] equal to 130[latex]^{\circ}[/latex] .One of the parallel lines trip due to the relay maloperation at an instant when [latex]\delta (t) = 130^{\circ}[/latex] as shown in the figure. The maximum value of the per unit line reactance, x such that the system does not lose synchronism subsequent to this tripping is
solution: The curve [latex]P_{e1}[/latex] and [latex]P_{e2}[/latex] represents power before the tripping of one line and after the tripping respectively [latex]P_{e\; max\;2}=\frac{EV}{X_2}[/latex] [latex]X_2=0.1+X[/latex] for max value of X system will not loose synchronization, if at [latex]\delta _2[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{e2} &=P_m \\ \frac{EV}{X_2} \sin \delta _2&=P_m \\ \frac{1 \times 1}{X_2} \sin 130^{\circ}&=1 \\ X_2&=0.77 \\ X&=0.67 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 157 A three phase balanced star connected voltage source with frequency [latex]\omega[/latex] rad/s
is connected to a star connected balanced load which is purely inductive. The
instantaneous line currents and phase to neutral voltages are denoted by ([latex]i_{a},i_{b},i_{c}[/latex]) and ([latex]v_{an},v_{bn},v_{cn}[/latex]) respectively, and their rms values are denoted by V and I. If [latex]R=[v_{an}\; v_{bn}\; v_{cn}]\begin{bmatrix} 0 & \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} &-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}& 0&\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} & 0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex], then the magnitude of R is
solution: [latex]R=\begin{bmatrix} V_{an} &V_{bn} &V_{cn} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 0 & \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\\ -\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} & 0 & -\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}& -\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} &0 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} i_a\\ i_b\\ i_c \end{bmatrix}\;...(i)[/latex] Assuming phase sequence abc, taking [latex]V_{an}[/latex] as the reference, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{an}&=V\angle 0^{\circ}; \\ V_{bn}&=V\angle -120^{\circ}; \\ V_{cn}&=V\angle 120^{\circ};\;\;...(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] V is the rms value of [latex]V_{an}, V_{bn}[/latex]  and [latex]V_{cn}[/latex] I is the rms value of [latex]i_{a}, i_{b}[/latex]  and [latex]i_{c}[/latex] From equation (ii), we can say [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{an}&=\sqrt{2}V \sin \omega t;\\ V_{bn}&=\sqrt{2}V \sin (\omega t-120^{\circ}); \\ V_{cn}&=\sqrt{2}V \sin (\omega t+120^{\circ});\;\;...(iii) \end{aligned}[/latex] and similarly due to lagging load [latex]\begin{aligned} i_{a}&=\sqrt{2}I \sin (\omega t-90^{\circ});\\ i_{b}&=\sqrt{2}I \sin (\omega t-90-120^{\circ}); \\ i_{c}&=\sqrt{2}I \sin (\omega t-90+120^{\circ}) \end{aligned}[/latex] From equation (iii) by considering line values of voltage [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{ab}&=\sqrt{6}V \sin (\omega t+30^{\circ});\\ V_{bc}&=\sqrt{6}V \sin (\omega t-90^{\circ}); \\ V_{ac}&=\sqrt{6}V \sin (\omega t+150^{\circ}) \end{aligned}[/latex] From equation (i), we have [latex]\begin{aligned} &=-\left [ \frac{V_{bn}-V_{cn}}{\sqrt{3}}\frac{V_{cn}-V_{cn}}{\sqrt{3}}\frac{V_{an}-V_{bn}}{\sqrt{3}} \right ]\begin{bmatrix} i_a\\ i_b\\ i_c \end{bmatrix}\\ &=-[(\sqrt{2}V \sin (\omega t-90^{\circ}))(\sqrt{2}I \sin (\omega t-90^{\circ}))\\ &+(\sqrt{2}V \sin (\omega t+150^{\circ}))(\sqrt{2}I \sin (\omega t+150^{\circ}))\\ &+(\sqrt{2}V \sin (\omega t+30^{\circ}))(\sqrt{2}I \sin (\omega t+30^{\circ}))]\\ \because \; &\left ( \sin A \sin B= \frac{\cos (A-B)-\cos (A+B)}{2}\right )\\ &=-[VI-VI \cos (2\omega t+180^{\circ})+VI\\ & -VI \cos (2\omega t+300^{\circ})+VI-VI \cos (2\omega t+60^{\circ})+]\\ &=-[3VI-VI \cos (2\omega t-180^{\circ})\\ &+ \cos (2\omega t+300^{\circ})+ \cos (2\omega t+60^{\circ})]\\ &=R=-3VI\\ &=|R|=3VI \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 158 Consider the protection system shown in the figure below. The circuit breakers
numbered from 1 to 7 are of identical type. A single line to ground fault with zero
fault impedance occurs at the midpoint of the line (at point F), but circuit breaker
4 fails to operate ("Stuck breaker"). If the relays are coordinated correctly, a
valid sequence of circuit breaker operation is
solution: If the relays are co-ordinated correctly, due to fault ina particular section, relay in that section must operate first, then relays in near by section if first fails, it is back up protection. Thus, the sequence is [5,6,7,3,1,2].

question:
Question 159 The total reactance and total suspectance of a lossless overhead EHV line,
operating at 50 Hz, are given by 0.045 pu and 1.2 pu respectively. If the velocity
of wave propagation is  [latex]3 \times 10^{5}[/latex] km/s, then the approximate length of the line is
solution: For loss less line, [latex]\begin{aligned} \beta &=\sqrt{\omega L\cdot \omega C}\\ \beta &=\sqrt{0.045 \times 1.2}\\ \beta &=\frac{2 \pi f l}{v}\\ l&=\frac{0.2324 \times 3 \times 10^5}{2 \pi \times 50}\\&=222 km \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 160 The figure below shows a three phase self-commutated voltage source converter
connected to a power system. The converter's dc bus capacitor is marked as C
in the figure. The circuit in initially operating in steady state with [latex]\delta[/latex]=0 and the
capacitor dc voltage is equal to [latex]V_{dc0}[/latex]. You may neglect all losses and harmonics.
What action should be taken to increase the capacitor dc voltage slowly to a new
steady state value.
solution: To increase the capacitor dc voltage, energy has to be supplied by the generator to capacitor through converter. Power flow from higher angle to lower angle. As angle of induced emf of generator is 0, so [latex]\delta[/latex] should be made negative to make the power flow in required direction.

options.A: Make [latex]\delta[/latex] positive and maintain it at a positive value
options.B: Make [latex]\delta[/latex] positive and return it to its original value
options.C: Make [latex]\delta[/latex] negative and maintain it at a negative value
options.D: Make [latex]\delta[/latex] negative and return it to its original value

question: Question 162 Two regional systems, each having several synchronous generators and loads are inter connected by an ac line and a HVDC link as shown in the figure. Which of the following statements is true in the steady state :
solution: Both region are connected by HVDC link as well as AC line. So AC link is possible when both regions have frequency. By changing fringe angle ([latex]\alpha[/latex]) of converter, we can change the power sharing, between the AC line and HVDC link.

options.A: Both regions need not have the same frequency
options.B: The total power flow between the regions ([latex]P_{ac}+P_{dc}[/latex]) can be changed by controlled the HDVC converters alone

The power sharing between the ac line and the HVDC link can be changed
by controlling the HDVC converters alone.

question: Question 163 The incremental cost curves in Rs/MWhr for two generators supplying a common load of 700 MW are shown in the figures. The maximum and minimum generation limits are also indicated. The optimum generation schedule is :
solution: Maximum incremental cost in Rs/Mwhr for generator A =600 (at 450 MW) Minimum incremental cost in Rs/Mwhr for generator B =650 (at 150 MW) As maximum value of incremental cost of A is less than minimum value of B. Therefore, generator 'A' will operate at its maximum (o/p) 450 MW and B at (700-450)=250 MW.

options.A: Generator A : 400 MW, Generator B : 300 MW
options.B: Generator A : 350 MW, Generator B : 350 MW
options.C: Generator A : 450 MW, Generator B : 250 MW
options.D: Generator A : 425 MW, Generator B : 275 MW

question: Question 164 Consider the transformer connections in a part of a power system shown in the figure. The nature of transformer connections and phase shifts are indicated for all but one transformer. Which of the following connections, and the corresponding phase shift [latex]\theta[/latex], should be used for the transformer between A and B ?
solution: Taking [latex]V_1[/latex] as the reference [latex]V_1=220\angle 0^{\circ}kV[/latex] [latex]\angle \theta _1=0^{\circ}[/latex] Phase difference [latex]V_2[/latex] and [latex]V_1[/latex] is [latex]0^{\circ}[/latex]. So, [latex]V_2=400\angle 0^{\circ}kV[/latex] [latex]V_2[/latex] leads  [latex]V_3[/latex] by [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex]. So, [latex]V_3=15\angle -30^{\circ}kV[/latex] [latex]\angle \theta _3=-30^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]V_3[/latex] lags  [latex]V_4[/latex] by [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex]. [latex]\angle \theta _3=\angle \theta _4-30^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]\angle \theta _4=\angle \theta _3+30^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]\angle \theta _4=-30^{\circ}+30^{\circ}=0^{\circ}[/latex] Phase difference between [latex]V_1[/latex] and [latex]V_2[/latex] is [latex]\theta[/latex] [latex]\theta =\angle \theta _1-\angle \theta _4=0-0=0^{\circ}[/latex]

question: Question 165 For a power System the admittance and impedance matrices for the fault studies are as fallows [latex]Y_{bus}=\begin{bmatrix} -j8.75 & j1.25 & j2.50\\ j1.25& -j6.25 & j2.50\\ j2.50 & -j2.50 & -j5.00 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]Z_{bus}=\begin{bmatrix} j0.16 & j0.08 & j0.12\\ j0.08 & j0.24 & j0.16\\ j0.12 & j0.16 & j0.34 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The pre-fault voltages are 1.0 pu. at all the buses. The system was unloaded prior to the fault. A solid 3-phase fault takes place at bus 2. The per unit fault feeds from generators connected to buses 1 and 2 respectively are
solution: [latex]Y_{ii}=[/latex] Sum of the admittance directly connected to [latex]i^{th}[/latex] bus [latex]\begin{aligned} Y_{iL} &=Y_{i0}+Y_{i1}+...+Y_in \; \; (Y_{ii} \text{ excluded})\\ Y_{ik} &=--y_{ik} \\ Y_{11} &=Y_{10}+Y_{12}+Y_{13} \\ Y_{12} &=-y_{12} \\ Y_{13} &=-y_{13} \\ Y_{10}&=Y_{11}+Y_{12}+Y_{13} \\ &= -j8.75+j1.25+j2.5\\ &= -j5\;p.u.\\ &\text{Similarly,} \\ Y_{20}&=Y_{22}+Y_{21}+Y_{23} \\ Y_{20}&=-j6.25+j1.25+j2.5 \\ Y_{20}&=-j2.5\; p.u. \\ Z_{10}&=\frac{1}{y_{10}}=\frac{1}{-j5}=j0.2 \\ Z_{20}&=\frac{1}{y_{20}}=\frac{1}{-j2.5}=j0.4 \\ I_{Gi}^f&= \frac{E_{Gi}-V_i^t}{Z_{i0}}\\ [\text{Current} &\text{ fed by generator i during fault}] \\ E_{G1} &=E_{G2}=1\angle 0^{\circ} \\ &\text{[The system was unloaded]} \\ &\text{Current fed by generator 1} \\ I_{G1}^f &=\frac{E_{G1}-V_1^f}{Z_{10}}=\frac{1\angle 0^{\circ}-0.67\angle 0^{\circ}}{j0.2}\\ &=1.65\angle -90^{\circ}\; p.u.\\ &\text{Current fed by generator 2,} \\ I_{G2}^f &=\frac{E_{G2}-V_2^f}{Z_{20}}=\frac{1\angle 0^{\circ}-0}{j0.4}\\ &=2.5\angle -90^{\circ}\; p.u.\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 166 For a power system the admittance and impedance matrices for the fault studies are as fallows [latex]Y_{bus}=\begin{bmatrix} -j8.75 & j1.25 & j2.50\\ j1.25& -j6.25 & j2.50\\ j2.50 & -j2.50 & -j5.00 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]Z_{bus}=\begin{bmatrix} j0.16 & j0.08 & j0.12\\ j0.08 & j0.24 & j0.16\\ j0.12 & j0.16 & j0.34 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] The pre-fault voltages are 1.0 pu. at all the buses. The system was unloaded prior to the fault. A solid 3-phase fault takes place at bus 2. The post fault voltages at buses 1 and 3 in per unit respectively are
solution: [latex]\text{Pre fault }V_{BUS}=\begin{bmatrix} V_1^0\\ V_2^0\\ V_3^0 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\angle 0^{\circ}\\ 1\angle 0^{\circ}\\ 1\angle 0^{\circ} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]\text{Fault current }= I^f=\frac{V_r^0}{Z_{rr}+Z_f}[/latex] Solid [latex]3-\phi[/latex] fault occurs at bus 2, r=2 and [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_F&=0 \\ Z_{rr}&=Z_{22}=j0.24 \\ V_r^0&=V_1^0=1\angle 0^{\circ} \\ I^f&=\frac{V_2^0}{Z_{22}+Z_f}\\ &=\frac{1\angle 0^{\circ} }{j0.4+0}\\&=-j4.167 \; p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex] Post fault voltage at bus i is given by [latex]V_i^f=V_i^0-Z_{ir}I^f[/latex] Post fault voltage at bus, i=1 [latex]\begin{aligned} V_1^f&=V_1^0-Z_{12}I^f \\ &= 1\angle 0^{\circ}-j0.08 \times (-j4.167)\\ &= 0.67 \; p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex] Post fault voltage at bus, i=3 [latex]\begin{aligned} V_3^f&=V_3^0-Z_{32}I^f \\ &= 1\angle 0^{\circ}-j0.16 \times (-j4.167)\\ &= 0.33 \; p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 167 A generator feeds power to an infinite bus through a double circuit transmission line. A 3-phase fault occurs at the middle point of one of the lines. The infinite bus voltage of the generator is 1.1 pu and the equivalent transfer admittance during fault is 0.8 pu. The 100 MVA generator has an inertia constant of 5 MJ/MVA and it was delivering 1.0 pu power prior of the fault with rotor power angle of 30[latex]^\circ[/latex]. The system frequency is 50 Hz. If the initial accelerating power is X pu, the initial acceleration in elect [latex]deg/sec^2[/latex],
and the inertia constant in MJ-sec/elect deg respectively will be
solution: Inertia constant (in MJ-s/elec deg) [latex]M=\frac{GH}{180f}[/latex] where, G = Machine rating = 100MVA H = Ineria constant in MJ/MVA = 5 MJ/MVA [latex]\begin{aligned} M&=\frac{GH}{180f}=\frac{5 \times 100}{180 \times 50} \\ &=0.056\; \text{MJ-s/elec deg }\\ M_{in \; pu}&= \frac{H}{180f}=\frac{5}{180 \times 50}\\ \alpha &= \text{Acceleration in elect deg/sec}\\ M\alpha &=P_a \\ P_a&= \text{Accelerating power}=X \\ \alpha &= \frac{P_a}{M}=\frac{X}{(5/180 \times 50)}\\ &= 1800 \; \text{X elec deg/sec} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 168 A generator feeds power to an infinite bus through a double circuit transmission line. A 3-phase fault occurs at the middle point of one of the lines. The infinite bus voltage of the generator is 1.1 pu and the equivalent transfer admittance during fault is 0.8 pu. The 100 MVA generator has an inertia constant of 5 MJ/MVA and it was delivering 1.0 pu power prior of the fault with rotor power angle of 30[latex]^\circ[/latex]. The system frequency is 50 Hz. The initial accelerating power (in pu) will be
solution: Before fault: Electrical power delivered by the generator [latex]=P_e=1.0p.u.[/latex] Mechanical input to the generator [latex]=P_m[/latex] At steady state, [latex]P_m=P_e=1.0p.u.[/latex] During Fault: Initial rotorr angle [latex]=\delta =30^{\circ}[/latex] Internal voltage of the generator [latex]=|E_g|=1.1p.u.[/latex] Voltage of the bus [latex]=|V|=1p.u.[/latex] Equivalent transfer admittance =0.8 Transfer reactance [latex]=x=\frac{1}{0.8}=1.25[/latex] [latex](P_e)_f = [/latex] Electrical power delivered by the generator [latex]\text{During fault}=\frac{|E_g||V_t|}{x}\sin \delta[/latex] [latex](P_e)_f=\frac{1.1 \times 1}{1.25}\sin 30^{\circ}=0.44p.u.[/latex] Mechanical input do not change during fault So, [latex](P_m)_f=1p.u.[/latex] Accelerating power [latex]\begin{aligned} P_a&= (P_m)_f-(P_e)_f\\ P_a&=1-0.44 \\ &= 0.56p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 170 A generator is connected through a 20 MVA, 13.8/138 kV step down transformer,
to a transmission line. At the receiving end of the line a load is supplied through
a step down transformer of 10 MVA, 138/69 kV rating. A 0.72 pu. load, evaluated
on load side transformer ratings as base values , is supplied from the above
system. For system base values of 10 MVA and 69 kV in load circuit, the value of
the load (in per unit) in generator will be
solution: Base value on load circuit, [latex]\begin{aligned} (MVA)_B&=10MVA\\ (kV)_B&=69 kV \end{aligned}[/latex] Base impedance [latex]=\frac{69^2}{10}=476.1[/latex] Value of load in ohm [latex]=Z_L[/latex] = value of load in p.u. x Base impedance [latex]\Rightarrow \; Z_L=0.72 \times 476.1=342.8\Omega[/latex] Base value in generator circuit, [latex]\begin{aligned} (MVA)_B&=20MVA\\ (kV)_B&=13.8 kV \end{aligned}[/latex] Base impedance, [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_B&= \frac{(kV)_B^2}{(MVA)_B}=\frac{13.8^2}{20}\\ Z_B&=9.522\Omega \\ \frac{Z_L}{Z_B} &=\frac{342.8}{9.522}=36\;p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 171 Three identical star connected resistors of 1.0 pu are connected to an unbalanced
3-phase supply. The load neutral is isolated. The symmetrical components of the
line voltages in pu. are: [latex]V_{ab1}=X\angle \theta _{1},V_{ab2}=Y\angle \theta _{2}[/latex]. If all the pu calculations are with the respective base values, the phase to neutral sequence voltages are
solution: Positive (negative ) sequence component of line voltage is [latex]\sqrt{3}[/latex] time of positive (negative) sequence component of phase voltage and leads (lags) by [latex]30^{\circ}[/latex] in actual value but in p.u. on respective base value they are equal., [latex]V_{an}^{(1)}=X\angle \theta _1-30^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]V_{an}^{(2)}=Y\angle \theta _2+30^{\circ}[/latex]

question:
Question 172 A single phase transmission line and a telephone line are both symmetrically
strung one below the other, in horizontal configurations, on a common tower, The
shortest and longest distances between the phase and telephone conductors are
2.5 m and 3 m respectively.
The voltage (volt/km) induced in the telephone circuit, due to 50 Hz current of
100 amps in the power circuit is
solution: where, [latex]P_1[/latex] and [latex]P_2[/latex] from power line and [latex]T_1[/latex] and [latex]T_2[/latex] from telephone line Current in power circuit =I=100 A Mutual inductance between power line and telephone line [latex]\begin{aligned} M_{PT}&=4 \times 10^{-7} \ln \left ( \frac{D_2}{D_1} \right )H/m \\ &=4 \times 10^{-7} \ln \left ( \frac{3}{2.5} \right )H/m \\ &= 0.73 \times 10^{-7} H/m \end{aligned}[/latex] Voltage induced in the telephone line [latex]\begin{aligned} |V_T|&=\omega M_{PT}I\\ &= 2 \pi \times 50 \times 0.73 \times 10^{-7} \times 100\\ |V_T|&=2.29 \times 10^{-3}V/m=2.29 V/km \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 173 The A, B, C , D constants of a 220 kV line are : [latex]A=D=0.94\angle 1^{\circ}[/latex], [latex]B=130\angle 73^{\circ}[/latex], [latex]C=0.001\angle 90^{\circ}[/latex]. If the sending end voltage of the line for a given load delivered at nominal voltage
is 240 kV, the % voltage regulation of the line is
solution: Sending end volatge [latex]=V_s=240kV[/latex] Full-load receiving end voltage [latex]=(V_R)_{FL}=220kV [/latex] [latex]V_{s(per \; phase)}=\frac{240}{\sqrt{3}}kV [/latex] As we know, [latex]V_{s(per \; phase)}=AV_{R(per \; phase)}+BI_R [/latex] At no-load, [latex]I_R=0 [/latex] No-load receiving end voltage (per phase) [latex] =(V_R)_{NL(per \; phase)}[/latex] [latex] =\frac{V_{s(per \; phase)}}{A}[/latex] [latex] =\frac{240}{\sqrt{3} \times 0.94}=\frac{255.32}{\sqrt{3}}kV [/latex] No-load receiving end voltage ( line to line) [latex]=(V_R)_{NL}=255.32 kV [/latex] % voltage regulation [latex]=\frac{(V_R)_{NL}-(V_R)_{FL}}{(V_R)_{FL}} \times 100\\ =\frac{255.32-220}{220} \times 100\approx 16%[/latex]

question:
Question 174 A 400 V, 50 Hz, three phase balanced source supplies power to a star connected
load whose rating is 12[latex]\sqrt{3}[/latex] kVA, 0.8 pf (lag). The rating (in kVAR) of the delta connected (capacitive) reactive power bank necessary to bring the pf to unity is
solution: Rating of the load [latex]12\sqrt{3}[/latex] at 0.8 pf lag Active power demand of the load [latex]\begin{aligned} P_L&=12\sqrt{3} \times 0.8=16.63kW\\ \cos \theta &=0.8\\ \Rightarrow \;\sin \theta &=0.6 \end{aligned}[/latex] Reactive power demand of the laod [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_L&=12\sqrt{3} \sin \theta \\ &=12\sqrt{3} \times 0.6\\ Q_L&=12.47 \text{ kVAR} \end{aligned}[/latex] For unity pf, the total reactive power is zero. Assuming kVAR rating of capacitor bank [latex]=Q_C[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} &Q_C+Q_L=0\\ &Q_C=-Q_L=-12.47\text{ kVAR} \end{aligned}[/latex] So, capacitor banks supplies 12.47 KVAR reactive power to the load.

question: Question 175 An HVDC link consist of rectifier, inverter transmission line and other equipments. Which one of the following is true for this link ?
solution: The rectifier consumes reactive power and inverter supplies reactive power from/to the respective connected AC systems because no reactive power can be transmitted over a dc link.

options.A: The transmission line produces/ supplies reactive power
options.B:
The rectifier consumes reactive power and the inverter supplies reactive
power from/ to the respective connected AC systems
options.C: Rectifier supplies reactive power and the inverted consumers reactive power to/ from the respective connected AC systems
options.D:
Both the converters (rectifier and inverter) consume reactive power from
the respective connected AC systems

question: Question 176 In a biased differential relay the bias is defined as a ratio of
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} N_0k|I_1-I_2|& \gt \frac{N_r}{2}k|I_1+I_2|\\ |I_1-I_2|&\gt \frac{N_r}{N_0}\left | \frac{I_1+I_2}{2} \right | \end{aligned}[/latex] where, [latex]N_0=[/latex] number of turns of the operating coil [latex]N_r=[/latex] number of turns of the restraining coil. The relay operates when the magnitude of the difference in the currents at the two ends of a protected element exceeds a certain percentage [latex]((N_r/N_0)/100)[/latex] of half the magnitude of their sum. Hence, the name percentage differentail relay.

options.A: number of turns of restraining and operating coil
options.B: operating coil current and restraining coil current
options.C: fault current and operating coil current
options.D: fault current and restraining coil current

question: Question 177 Keeping in view the cost and overall effectiveness, the following circuit breaker is best suited for capacitor bank switching
solution: The arc time constant is the least (a few [latex]\mu s[/latex]) in vaccum circuit breakers as compared to other breaker types. The rapid building up of dielectric strength after final arc extinction ([latex]20kV/\mu s[/latex]) is unique feature of VCBs. These arc, therefore, ideally suited for capacitor switching.

question:
Question 178 The concept of an electrically short, medium and long line is primarily based on
the
solution: [latex]L=[/latex] length of line If  [latex]L \leq 80[/latex] km The line id short line. If  [latex]80km \lt L \leq 250km[/latex] The line is medium line. If [latex]L \gt 250km[/latex] The line is long line.

question: Question 179 At a 220 kV substation of a power system, it is given that the three-phase fault level is 4000 MVA and single-line to ground fault level is 5000 MVA Neglecting the resistance and the shunt suspectances of the system. The zero sequence driving point reactance at the bus is
solution: Let negative sequence reactance [latex]=X_2[/latex] Assuming, [latex]X_2=X_1[/latex] and zero sequence reactance [latex]=X_0[/latex] In single-line to ground fault, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Fault level (MVA)}&=5000MVA\\ \text{Fault current}&=I_f=\frac{\text{Fault-level}}{\sqrt{3} \times V_{prefault}}\\ &=\frac{5000 \times 10^6}{\sqrt{3} \times 220 \times 10^3}\\ &=13.12kA\\ \text{In SLG fault}\\ \text{Positive}& \text{ sequence current}\\ I_{a1}&=\frac{I_f}{3}=\frac{13.12}{3}=4.37kA\\ I_{a1}&=\frac{V_{prefault}(\text(per phase))}{X_1+X_2+X_0}\\ 4.37&=\frac{220/\sqrt{3}}{2X_1+X_0}\\ &=\frac{127}{2 \times 12.1+X_0}\\ X_0&\approx 4.84\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 180 At a 220 kV substation of a power system, it is given that the three-phase fault level is 4000 MVA and single-line to ground fault level is 5000 MVA Neglecting the resistance and the shunt suspectances of the system. The positive sequence driving point reactance at the bus is
solution: Fault level (in MVA) = [latex]\sqrt{3} \times[/latex] prefault line voltage (kV) [latex] \times[/latex] fault current (in kA) Pre-fault line voltage [latex]=V_{prefault}=220kV[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} 3-\phi \text{ fault level} &=4000 MVA \\ \sqrt{3} V_{present}I_f&=4000MVA \\ I_f&=\frac{4000 \times 10^6}{\sqrt{3}\times 220 \times 10^3}\\ &=10.5kA \end{aligned}[/latex] Let positive sequence driving point reactance =[latex]=X_1[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} X_1&=\frac{V_{present}/\sqrt{3}}{I_f}\\ X_1&=\frac{220/\sqrt{3}}{10.5}=12.1\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 181 A generator with constant 1.0 p.u. terminal voltage supplies power through
a step-up transformer of 0.12 p.u. reactance and a double-circuit line to an
infinite bus bar as shown in the figure. The infinite bus voltage is maintained at
1.0 p.u. Neglecting the resistances and suspectances of the system, the steady
state stability power limit of the system is 6.25 p.u. If one of the double-circuit
is tripped, then resulting steady state stability power limit in p.u. will be
solution: Induced emf of the generator [latex]=|t_g|=1p.u.[/latex] Termincal voltage [latex]=|V_t|=1p.u.[/latex] Reactance of transformer [latex]=X_t=0.12p.u.[/latex] When double-circuit line is connected Reactance of line [latex]=X||X=\frac{X}{2}[/latex] Steady state stability power limit [latex]\begin{aligned} P_1&= \frac{|E_g||V_t|}{X_t+\frac{X}{2}}=\frac{|X|}{0.12+\frac{X}{2}}\\ 6.25&= \frac{1}{0.12+\frac{X}{2}}\\ X&= 0.08p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex] When one of the double circuit is tripled, steady state stability power limit [latex]=P_2=\frac{|E_g||V_t|}{X_t+X}=\frac{|X|}{0.12+0.08}=5p.u.[/latex]

question:
Question 182 A load centre is at an equidistant from the two thermal generating stations [latex]G_{1}[/latex] and [latex]G_{2}[/latex] as shown in the figure. The fuel cost characteristic of the generating stations are given by [latex]F_{1}=a+bP_{1}+cP_{1}^{2} Rs/hour [/latex] [latex]F_{2}=a+bP_{2}+2cP_{2}^{2} Rs/hour[/latex] Where [latex]P_1 \; and \; P_2[/latex] are the generation in MW of [latex]G_{1}[/latex] and [latex]G_{2}[/latex], respectively. For most
economic generation to meet 300 MW of load [latex]P_1 \; and \; P_2[/latex] respectively, are
solution: Fuel-cost curve of generating station 1 [latex]F_1=a+bP_1+cP_1^2 \; \text{Rs/hour}[/latex] Fuel-cost curve of generating station 2 [latex]F_2=a+bP_2+2cP_2^2 \; \text{Rs/hour}[/latex] The slope of the fuel-cost curve i.e. [latex]\frac{dF_i}{dP_i}[/latex] is called the incremental fuel-cost (IC) and is expressed in Rs/MWh. [latex]\begin{aligned} IC_1&=\frac{dF_1}{dP_1}=b+2cP_1 \\ IC_2&=\frac{dF_2}{dP_2}=b42cP_2 \end{aligned}[/latex] For economic generation [latex]\begin{aligned} IC_1&=IC_2\\ b+2cP_1&=b+4cP_2\\ P_1&=2P_2\;\;...(i) \\ &\text{To meet 300 MW of load}\\ P_1+P_2&=300\;\;...(ii)\\ &\text{Solving eq. (i) and (ii)}\\ P_1&=200MW\\ P_2&=100MW \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 183 The network shown in the given figure has impedances in p.u. as indicated. The
diagonal element [latex]Y_{22}[/latex] of the bus admittance matrix [latex]Y_{BUS}[/latex] of the network is
solution: Impedance between bus (1) and bus (2) [latex]=Z_{12}=j0.1[/latex] admittance [latex]=Y_{12}=\frac{1}{Z_{12}}=\frac{1}{j0.1}=-j10 p.u.[/latex] Impedance between bus (2) and bus (3) [latex]=Z_{23}=j0.1[/latex] admittance [latex]=Y_{23}=\frac{1}{Z_{23}}=\frac{1}{j0.1}=-j10 p.u.[/latex] Impedance between bus (2) and bus (0) [latex]=Z_{20}=-j20[/latex] admittance [latex]=Y_{20}=\frac{1}{Z_{20}}=\frac{1}{-j20}=j0.05 p.u.[/latex] [latex]Y_{22}=Y_{20}+Y_{12}+Y_{23}=j0.05-j10-j10=-j19.95\;p.u.[/latex]

question:
Question 184 At an industrial sub-station with a 4 MW load, a capacitor of 2 MVAR is
installed to maintain the load power factor at 0.97 lagging. If the capacitor goes
out of service, the load power factor becomes
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_C &=P_1(\tan \phi _1 - \tan \phi _2) \\ 2&=4(\tan \phi _1 - \tan (\cos ^{-1} 0.97))\\ \cos \phi &=0.8 \; lag \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 185 The parameters of a transposed overhead transmission line are given as : Self reactance [latex]X_{s}=0.5\Omega[/latex]/km and Mutual reactance [latex]X_{m}=0.1\Omega[/latex]/km The positive sequence reactance [latex]X_1[/latex] and zero sequence reactance [latex]X_0[/latex], respectively in [latex]\Omega[/latex]/km are
solution: For transmission line Positive sequence impedance, [latex] X_1=X_s-X_m=0.4-0.1=0.3\Omega /km[/latex] Zero sequence impedance, [latex] X_0=X_s+2X_m=0.4+0.2=0.6\Omega /km[/latex]

question: Question 186 High Voltage DC (HVDC) transmission is mainly used for
solution: HVDC system are economical for long distance bulk power transmission by overhead lines, due to reduced power and cable costs. The DC line is an asynchronous link and it can interconnect two rigid systems operating at different frequencies. Converters and converter transformers requires reactive power in the operation. The AC/DC converters are sources of harmonics on AC as well as DC side.

options.A: bulk power transmission over very long distances
options.B: inter-connecting two systems with same nominal frequency
options.C: eliminating reactive power requirement in the operation
options.D: minimizing harmonics at the converter stations

question: Question 187 The insulation strength of an EHV transmission line is mainly governed by
solution: NOTE: At transmission line voltages upto around 230 kV, the insulation level is dictated by the requirement of protection against lighting. For voltages from 230 kV to 700 kV, both switching transients and lightning overlotages must be accounted for in deciding the insulation levels. In EHV ([latex]\gt[/latex] 700 kV) switching surges cause overvoltages than lightning and are therefore mainly responsible for insulation level decision.

question:
Question 188 An 800 kV transmission line has a maximum power transfer capacity of P. If it
is operated at 400 kV with the series reactance unchanged, the new maximum
power transfer capacity is approximately
solution: Power transfer capacity [latex]\propto V^2[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{P_1}{P_2}&=\frac{V_1^2}{V_2^2} \\ P_2&=P_1 \times \left ( \frac{V_2}{V_1} \right )^2 \\ &= P \times \left ( \frac{400}{800} \right )^2\\ &=\frac{P}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 189 The p.u. parameter for a 500 MVA machine on its own base are: inertia M = 20 p.u.;  reactance X = 2 p.u. The p.u. values of inertia and reactance on 100 MVA common base, respectively, are
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} (M_{pu})_{new}&=(M_{pu})_{old} \times \frac{(MVA)_{old}}{(MVA)_{new}} \\ &= 20 \times \frac{500}{100}=100\; p.u.\\ (X_{pu})_{new} &=(X_{pu})_{old} \times \frac{(MVA)_{old}}{(MVA)_{new}} \times \frac{(kV)^2_{old}}{(kV)^2_{new}}\\ &=2 \times \frac{100}{500}=0.4 \;\;[(kV)_{old}=(kV)_{new}] \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 190 A 50 Hz, 4-pole, 500 MVA, 22 kV turbo-generator is delivering rated megavoltamperes
at 0.8 power factor. Suddenly a fault occurs reducing in electric power
output by 40%. Neglect losses and assume constant power input to the shaft.
The accelerating torque in the generator in MNm at the time of fault will be
solution: Before fault, mechanical input [latex](P_m)=[/latex] Electrical output [latex](P_e)[/latex] [latex]= 500 \times 0.8=400MW[/latex] After fault, mechanical input remains same [latex]=P_m=400MW[/latex] While electrical output reduces by 40 %. So, electrical output at the time of fault [latex]=(P_e)_f= 0.6 \times 400 =240MW[/latex] Accelerating power [latex]=P_a=P_m-(P_e)_f[/latex] [latex]=400-240=160MW[/latex] Synchronous speed (in rpm) [latex]N_s=\frac{120 \times f}{P}=\frac{120 \times 50}{4}=1500\; rpm[/latex] Synchronous speed (in rad/sec) [latex]\omega _s=\frac{2 \pi N_s}{60}=\frac{2 \pi \times 1500}{60}=157 \text{ rad/sec}[/latex] [latex]P_a=T_a\omega[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \;T_a\omega[/latex] (accelerating Torque) [latex]=\frac{P_a}{\omega _s}=\frac{160}{157}MN-m=1.018MN-m[/latex]

question:
Question 191 A 500 MVA, 50 Hz, 3-phase turbo-generator produces power at 22 kV.
Generator is Y-connected and its neutral is solidly grounded. It sequence
reactances are [latex]X_1 = X_2 = 0.15[/latex] pu and [latex]X_0 = 0.05[/latex] pu.It is operating at rated
voltage and disconnected from the rest of the system (no load). The magnitude
of the sub-transient line current for single line to ground fault at the generator
terminal in pu will be
solution: For single-line to ground fault, Since, the generator is operating at no-load and rated voltage [latex]\begin{aligned} E_a&=1\angle 0 p.u.\\ Z_1&=jX_1=j0.15p.u.\\ Z_2&=jX_2=j0.15p.u.\\ Z_0&=jX_0=j0.05p.u.\\ I_{a1}&=I_{a2}=I_{a3}\\ &=\frac{E_a}{Z_1+Z_2+Z_0}\\ &=\frac{1\angle 0^{\circ}}{j0.15+j0.15+j0.05}\\ &=2.857\angle 90^{\circ} pu\\ &\text{Fault current}=3I_{a1}\\ &=3 \times 2.857=8.57 pu \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 192 A 3-phase transmission line supplies [latex]\Delta[/latex]-connected load Z. The conductor 'c' of
the line develops an open circuit fault as shown in figure. The currents in the
lines are as shown on the diagram. The positive sequence current component in line
'a' will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} I_a&=10\angle 0^{\circ}A\\ I_b&=10\angle 180^{\circ}A\\ I_c&=0A\\ \alpha &=1\angle 120^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Positive sequence current component in line 'a' [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{a_1}&=\frac{1}{3}[I_a+\alpha I_b+\alpha ^2I_c]\\ &=\frac{1}{3}[10\angle 0^{\circ}+(1\angle 120^{\circ}) \times (10\angle 180^{\circ})+(1\angle 240^{\circ}) \times 0]\\ I_{a_1}&=5.77\angle -30^{\circ}A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 193 A 3-phase generator rated at 110 MVA, 11 kV is connected through circuit
breakers to a transformer. The generator is having direct axis sub-transient
reactance [latex]{X_{d}}''[/latex]=19%, transient reactance [latex]{X_{d}}'[/latex]=26% and synchronous reactance
=130%. The generator is operating at no load and rated voltage when a three
phase short circuit fault occurs between the breakers and the transformer. The
magnitude of initial symmetrical rms current in the breakers will be
solution: The generator is operating at no-load and rated voltage So,  [latex]E_g=1.0\angle 0^{\circ}p.u.[/latex] Initial symmetrical current [latex]\begin{aligned} I &=\frac{E_g}{X_d''} =\frac{1\angle 0}{j0.19}\\\\ I&=5.26 \angle -90^{\circ}p.u.\\ \text{Base current}&=\frac{(MVA)_{Base}}{\sqrt{3}(kV)_{Base}}\\ &=\frac{100}{\sqrt{3}\times 11} kA\\ |I|&=5.26 \times \text{Base current}\\ &=5.26 \times \frac{100}{\sqrt{3}\times 11} kA \\ &=30.37kA \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 194 A new generator having [latex]E_{g}[/latex] = 1.4[latex]\angle 30^{\circ}[/latex] pu [equivalent to (1.212 + j0.70) pu] and synchronous reactance '[latex]X_{s}[/latex] ' of 1.0 pu on the system base, is to be connected to a bus having voltage [latex]V_{t}[/latex] in the existing power system. This existing power system can be represented by Thevenin's voltage [latex]E_{th} = 0.9\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex] pu in series with Thevenin's impedance [latex]Z_{th} = 0.25\angle 90^{\circ}[/latex] pu. The magnitude of the bus voltage [latex]V_{t}[/latex] of the system in pu will be
solution: Thevenin's equivalent of existing system, wher, [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{th}&=0.25\angle 90^{\circ}\; p.u. \\ E_{th}&=0.9 \angle 0^{\circ}\; p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} I&=\frac{E_g-E_{th}}{jX_s+Z_{th}}\\ &=\frac{1.4\angle 30^{\circ}-0.9\angle 0^{\circ}}{j1+0.25\angle 90^{\circ}}\\ &=0.56-j0.25\;p.u.\\ V_t&=E_g-jIX_s\\ &=1.4\angle 30^{\circ}(0.56-j0.25)\times (j1)\\ &=0.973\angle 8.27^{\circ}\; p.u.\\ |V_t|&=0.973\; p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 195 The generalized circuit constants of a 3-phase, 220 kV rated voltage, medium
length transmission line are [latex]A=D=0.936+j0.016=0.936\angle 0.98^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]B=35.5+j138=142.0\angle 76.4 ^{\circ} \Omega[/latex] [latex] C=(-5.18+j914)\times 10^{-6}\Omega[/latex] If the load at the receiving end is 50 MW at 220 kV with a power factor of 0.9 lagging, then magnitude of line to line sending end voltage should be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A &=0.936 \angle 0.98^{\circ}\\ B &=142\angle 76.4^{\circ} \Omega \\ &=\frac{220}{\sqrt{3}}kV=127\angle 0^{\circ} kV\\ I_R&= \frac{50 \times 10^6}{\sqrt{3}\times 220 \times 10^3 \times 0.9}\\ &=145.8A \\ I_R&= 0.1458\angle -25.84^{\circ}kA\\ (\text{Power factor}&=0.9 \text{ lagging)} \\ V_s(\text{phase voltage}) &=AV_R+BI_R \\ V_s &=(0.936 \angle 0.98^{\circ}) \times (127\angle 0^{\circ})+(142 \angle 76.4^{\circ}) \\ &\times (0.1458 \angle -25.84^{\circ})\\ &=133.23 \angle 7.77^{\circ}\; kV\\ \text{ Line to line}& \text{ sending end voltage}\\ |V-s|_{l-l}&=\sqrt{3} \times 133.23 kV\\ &=230.78 kV \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 196 A lightning stroke discharges impulse current of 10 kA (peak) on a 400 kV
transmission line having surge impedance of 250[latex]\Omega[/latex]. The magnitude of transient
over-voltage travelling waves in either direction assuming equal distribution
from the point of lightning strike will be
solution: The impulse current of 10 KA (peak) will be equally divided in both directions since there is equal distribution on both sides. Then, magnitude of transient over voltage [latex]=10000 A \times 25=2500kV[/latex] (Assumed ideal impulse) Impulse available for zero time.

question:
Question 197 A 110 kV, single core coaxial, XLPE insulated power cable delivering power at
50 Hz, has a capacitance of 125 nF/km. If the dielectric loss tangent of XLPE is
[latex]2 \times 10^{-4}[/latex], then dielectric power loss in this cable in W/km is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{V(Phase voltage)} &=\frac{110}{\sqrt{3}}kV \\ C&=125 nF/km \\ \tan \delta &= 2 \times 10^{-4} \end{aligned}[/latex] Dielectric power loss in cable [latex]\begin{aligned} P&=V62 \omega C \tan \delta \\ P&=\left ( \frac{110 \times 10^3}{\sqrt{3}} \right )^2 \times 2 \\ & \times \pi \times 50 \times 125 \times 10^{-9} \times 2 \times 10^{-4}\\ &\approx 31.7 W/km \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 198 A 800 kV transmission line is having per phase line inductance of 1.1 mH/km
and per phase line capacitance of 11.68 nF/km. Ignoring the length of the line,
its ideal power transfer capability in MW is
solution: Parameter of the line Inductance =L = 1.1 mH/km Capacitance =C =11.68 nF/km Surge impedance of the line [latex]Z_s=\sqrt{\frac{L}{C}}=\sqrt{\frac{1.1 \times 10^{-3}}{11.68 \times 10^{-9}}}=306.88\Omega[/latex] Ideal power transfer capability [latex]=\frac{V{l-l}^2}{Z_s}=\frac{(800 \times 10^3)^2}{306.88}\approx 2085 \times 10^6\approx 2085MW[/latex]

question:

question:
Question 204 Total instantaneous power supplied by a 3-phase ac supply to a balanced R-L
load is
solution:
Impedance of the load [latex]=Z_L=R+j\omega L=|Z|\angle \theta _L[/latex] where, [latex]\theta _L=\tan ^{-1}\left ( \frac{\omega L}{R} \right )[/latex] Voltages of [latex]3-\phi[/latex] supply [latex]\begin{aligned}
 V_a&=V_m \sin \omega t \\ 
 V_b&=V_m \sin (\omega t-120^{\circ}) \\ 
V_c &=V_m \sin (\omega t+120^{\circ}) \\ 
 I_a&=\frac{V_a}{Z_L}=\frac{V_m \sin \omega t}{|Z|\angle \theta _L} \\ 
 &= I_M \sin (\omega t-\theta _L)\\ 
\text{where, } I_m&=\frac{V_m}{|Z|}\\
 \text{Similarly,}&\\
I_b&=I_m \sin (\omega t-120-\theta _L)\\
I_c&=I_m \sin (\omega t+120-\theta _L)\\
& \text{Instantaneous power}\\
&=P=V_aI_a+V_bI_b+V_cI_c\\
P&=V_mI_m[\sin \omega t\cdot \sin (\omega t-\theta _L)\\
&+\sin (\omega t-120^{\circ}) \cdot \sin (\omega t-120-\theta _L)\\
&+\sin (\omega t+120^{\circ})\cdot \sin (\omega t+120-\theta _L)]\\
&=\frac{V_mI_m}{2}[(\cos \theta _L -\cos(2\omega t-\theta _L) ) \\
&+(\cos \theta _L -\cos(2\omega t-240-\theta _L) )\\
&+(\cos \theta _L -\cos(2\omega t+240-\theta _L) )]\\
P&=\frac{3V_mI_m}{2}\cos \phi = \text{constant}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 205 three-phase alternator generating unbalanced voltages is connected
to an unbalanced load through a 3-phase transmission line as shown
in figure. The neutral of the alternator and the star point of the
load are solidly grounded. The phase voltages of the alternator are
[latex]E_{a}=10\angle 0^{\circ}V[/latex],  [latex]E_b=10\angle -90^{\circ}V[/latex], [latex]E_{c}=10\angle 120^{\circ}V[/latex]. The positive sequence component of the load current is
solution: Since both sides are grounded, we can take it as 3 independent circuit. Hence, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_a&=\frac{E_a}{Z_a}=\frac{10\angle 0^{\circ}}{2j}=-5jA\\ I_b&=\frac{E_b}{Z_b}=\frac{10\angle -90^{\circ}}{3j}=3.33\angle -180\\ I_c&=\frac{E_c}{Z_c}=\frac{10\angle 120^{\circ}}{4j}=2.5\angle 30\\ I_{a1}&=1/3(I_a+\alpha I_b+\alpha ^2I_c)\\ &=1/3[5\angle -90+3.33\angle (-180+120) +2.5\angle (240+30)]\\ &=1/3(5\angle 90+3.33\angle -60+2.5\angle 270)\\ &=3.510 \angle -81^{\circ}A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 206 A generator delivers power of 1.0 p.u. to an infinite bus through a purely
reactive network. The maximum power that could be delivered by the generator
is 2.0 p.u. A three-phase fault occurs at the terminals of the generator which
reduces the generator output to zero. The fault is cleared after [latex]t_{c}[/latex] second. The
original network is then restored. The maximum swing of the rotor angle is
found to be [latex]\delta _{max}[/latex] = 110 electrical degree. Then the rotor angle in electrical degrees at [latex]t =t_{c}[/latex] is
solution: Power generated by the generator [latex]\begin{aligned} P_e &=P_{max} \sin \delta \\ \text{At }\delta _0& \\ P_e&=1 pu \\ P_{max}&=2pu \\ \delta _{cr}&=\text{roto angle at }t =t_c\\ P_e&= P_{max} \sin \delta \\ 1&=2 \sin \delta _0 \\ \delta _0 &=30^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] During fault, [latex]P_e[/latex] become zero and the fault is cleared at [latex]\delta _{cr}[/latex], Mechanical input to the generator remains constant, [latex]P_m=1pu[/latex] Applying equal areal criterion, [latex]\begin{aligned} A_1&= A_2\\ A_1&= \int_{\delta _0}^{\delta _{cr}} (P_m-0)d\delta \\ &= P_m(\delta _{cr} -\delta _0)\;\;...(i)\\ A_2&=\int_{\delta _{cr}}^{\delta _{max}}(P_{max} \sin \delta -P_m)d\delta \\ &= P_{max}(\cos \delta _{cr} - \cos \delta _{max})\\ &-P_m(\delta _{max}-\delta _{cr})\;\;...(ii)\\ &\text{Equating eq. (i) and (ii),} \\ P_m(\delta _{cr}-\delta _0)&=P_{max}( \cos \delta _{cr} - \cos \delta _{max}) \\ &-P_m(\delta _{max} -\delta _{cr}) \\ \cos \delta _{cr} &= \frac{P_m}{P_{max}} (\delta _{max} - \delta _{0}) +\cos \delta _{max}\\ \cos \delta _{cr}&= \frac{1}{2} \times (110-30) \times \frac{\pi}{180}+\cos 110\\ \delta _{cr}&=69.14^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 207 A list of relays and the power system components protected by the relays are
given in Group-I and Group-II respectively. Choose the correct match from the four
choices given below:
solution: Buccholz Relay is used to protect transformers which operates when the oil level in the conservator pipe of a transformer is lowered by the accumulation of gas caued by a poor connection or by an incipient breakdown of insulation (slowly developing fault). A differential relay is a suitably connected over current relay operating on the difference of currents at the two ends of protected element.

question:
Question 208 Incremental fuel costs (in some appropriate unit) for a power plant consisting of
three generating units are [latex]IC_{1} = 20 + 0.3P_{1}[/latex] [latex]IC_{2} = 30 + 0.4P_{2}[/latex] [latex]IC_{3} = 30[/latex] Where [latex]P_{1}[/latex] is the power in MW generated by unit i for i=1,2 and 3. Assume
that all the three units are operating all the time. Minimum and maximum loads
on each unit are 50 MW and 300 MW respectively. If the plant is operating on
economic load dispatch to supply the total power demand of 700 MW, the power
generated by each unit is
solution: When [latex]P_1[/latex] is minimum i.e. [latex]P_1=50MW[/latex] [latex]IC_1=20+0.3 \times 50=35[/latex] When [latex]P_2[/latex] is minimum i.e. [latex]P_2=50MW[/latex] [latex]IC_2=30+0.4 \times 50=50[/latex] For minimum value of [latex]P_1[/latex] and [latex]P_2[/latex] [latex]IC_1[/latex] and [latex]IC_2 \gt IC_3[/latex] Therefore, [latex]P_3=300MW[/latex] [maximum load is assigned to unit 3] Remaining power is to shared by unit 1 and 2 So, [latex]P_1+P_2 = 700-300=400MW \;\;\;...(i)[/latex] For optimal operation, [latex]\begin{aligned} IC_1&=IC_2 \\ 20+0.3P_1&=30+0.4P_2 \\ 0.3P_1-0.4P_2&=10 \;\;...(ii)\end{aligned}[/latex] Solving equation (i) and (ii), we get [latex]\begin{aligned} P_1&=242.86\; MW\\ P_2&=157.14 \; MW \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 209 A 20-MVA, 6.6-kV, 3-phase alternator is connected to a 3-phase transmission
line. The per unit positive sequence, negative sequence and zero sequence
impedances of the alternator are j0.1, j0.1 and j0.04 respectively. The neutral
of the alternator is connected to ground through an inductive reactor of
j0.05 p.u. The per unit positive, negative and zero sequence impedances of
transmission line are
j0.1, j0.1 and j0.3, respectively. All per unit values are based on the machine
ratings. A solid ground fault occurs at one phase of the far end of the
transmission line. The voltage of the alternator neutral with respect to ground
during the fault is
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
&\text{For alternator}  \\ 
 Z_{1g}&=j0.1p.u. \\ 
 Z_{2g}&=j0.1p.u.\\ 
 Z_{3g}&=j0.04p.u. \\ 
 &\text{For line} \\ 
 Z_{1l}&=j0.1p.u. \\ 
 Z_{2l}&=j0.1p.u. \\ 
 Z_{0l}&=j0.3p.u. \\ 
 Z_{n}&=j0.05p.u. \\ 
 \text{Equivalent}& \text{sequence impedance:} \\ 
 Z_{1eq}&=Z_{1g}+Z_{1l} \\ 
 &= j0.1+j0.1=j0.2p.u.\\ 
Z_{2eq}&=Z_{2g}+Z_{2l} \\ 
 &= j0.1+j0.1=j0.2p.u.\\
Z_{0eq}&=Z_{0g}+Z_{0l}+3Z_n \\ 
 &= j0.04+j0.3+3 \times j0.05\\ 
 &=j0.49p.u. 
\end{aligned}[/latex] For single line to ground fault [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{a1}&=I_{a2}=I_{a0}\\ &=\frac{1\angle 0}{Z_{1eq}+Z_{2eq}+Z_{0eq}}\\ &=\frac{1\angle 0}{j(0.2+0.2+0.49)}\\ &=-j1.1236 p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex] Fault current [latex]=I_f=3I_{a1}=-j3.3708p.u.[/latex] Voltage of neutral w.r.t. ground [latex]\begin{aligned} V_n&=I_f \times Z_n \\ &= -j3.3708 \times j0.05\\ &= 0.16854p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex] Per phase base voltage [latex]\begin{aligned} V_p&=\frac{6.6}{\sqrt{3}}kV=\frac{6.6}{\sqrt{3}}\times 10^3V \\ V_n&=\frac{6.6}{\sqrt{3}} \times 0.16854 \times 10^3 \\ &= 642.2V \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 210 The bus impedance matrix of a 4-bus power system is given by [latex]Z_{bus}=\begin{bmatrix} j0.3435 & j0.2860 & j0.2723 & j0.2277\\ j0.2860& j0.3408 & j0.2586& j0.2414\\ j0.2723 & j0.2586 & j0.2791& j0.2209\\ j0.2277 &j0.2414 & j0.2209 & j0.2791 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] A branch having an impedance of  [latex]j0.2 \Omega[/latex] is connected between bus 2 and the reference. Then the values of [latex]Z_{22,new}[/latex] and [latex]Z_{23,new}[/latex] of the bus impedance matrix of the modified network are respectively
solution: [latex]Z_{B}(new)=Z_{B}(old)-\frac{1}{Z_{jj}+Z_{b}}\begin{bmatrix} Z_{1j}\\ \vdots \\ Z_{nj} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} Z_{j1} & \cdots & Z_{jn} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] New elements ([latex]Z_B[/latex]) is connected between [latex]j^{th}[/latex] and reference bus. Here, j=2, b=4 [latex]\therefore \;\;\frac{1}{Z_{jj}+Z_{b}}\begin{bmatrix} Z_{12}\\ Z_{22} \\ Z_{32}\\Z_{42} \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} Z_{21} & Z_{22} & Z_{23}& Z_{24} \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]\therefore \;\;\frac{1}{j0.3408+j0.2}\begin{bmatrix} j0.2860\\ j0.3408\\ j0.2586\\j0.2414 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} j0.2860 & j0.3408 & j0.2586& j0.2414 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] We are required only changes in [latex]Z_{22}Z_{23}[/latex] [latex]\begin{bmatrix} - & - & - & -\\ -& j0.2147 &j0.16296 & -\\ - & - &- &- \\ - &- & - & - \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{22}(new)&=Z_{22}(old)-j0.2147=j0.1260 \\ Z_{23}(new)&=Z_{23}(old)-j0.16296 \\ &= j0.2586-j0.16296=j0.0956\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 211 A 3-phase 11 kV generator feeds power to a constant power unity power factor
load of 100 MW through a 3-phase transmission line. The line-to line voltage
at the terminals of the machine is maintained constant at 11 kV. The per unit
positive sequence impedance of the line based on 100 MVA and 11 kV is j0.2.
The line to line voltage at the load terminals is measured to be less than 11 kV. The total reactive power to be injected at the terminals of the load to increase
the line-to-line voltage at the load terminals to 11 kV is
solution: [latex]|V_s|=|V_R|=11kV[/latex] p.u. impedance of the line = j0.2 p.u. Impedance of the line = p.u. impedance  x Base impedance [latex]x= j0.2 \times \frac{11^2}{100}=j0.242\Omega[/latex] Active power at receiving end [latex]=P_R=100 MW[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} P_R&=\frac{|V_s||V_R|}{x}\sin \delta \\ 100 &= \frac{11 \times 11}{0.242} \sin \delta \\ \delta &=11.54^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] Reactive power at receiving end [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_R&=\frac{|V_s||V_R|}{x}\cos \delta -\frac{|V_R|^2}{x} \\ &= \frac{11 \times 11}{0.242} \cos 11.54 -\frac{11^2}{0.242} \\ &=-10.1 \text{ MVAR} \end{aligned}[/latex] Since poer factor =1 Load reactive power should be zero Therefore, reactive power to be injected at terminals [latex]=-Q_R=-(-10.1)=10.1 \text{ MVAR}[/latex]

question:
Question 212 A dc distribution system is shown in figure with load current as marked. The
two ends of the feeder are fed by voltage sources such that [latex]V_P - V_Q = 3 V[/latex]. The
value of the voltage [latex]V_P[/latex] for a minimum voltage of 220 V at any point along the
feeder is
solution: Let current injected at point [latex]P=I_P[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} V_P-V_Q &=0.1(I_P-10)+0.15(I_P-30) \\ & +0.2(I_P-60) \\ 3&=0.45I_P-17.5 \\ I_P&=45.55A \end{aligned}[/latex] direction of current will be in opposite in section SQ, so, points will have minimum voltage, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_s&=220V\\ V_p&=V_s+0.1(I_p-10)+0.15(I_P-30)\\ &=220+0.1 \times (45.55-10)\\ &+0.15(45.55-30)\\ &\approx 225.89V \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 213 A surge of 20 kV magnitude travels along a lossless cable towards its junction
with two identical lossless overhead transmission lines. The inductance and the
capacitance of the cable are 0.4 mH and 0.5 [latex]\mu[/latex]F per km. The inductance and capacitance of the overhead transmission lines are 1.5 mH and 0.015 [latex]\mu[/latex]F per km. The magnitude of the voltage at the junction due to surge is
solution: where, [latex]z_1=z_2[/latex] Parameter of cable: Inducatance[latex]=L_C=0.4[/latex] mH/km and Capacitance [latex]=C_C=0.5\mu F/km[/latex] Surge impedance of the cable [latex]=Z_C=\sqrt{\frac{L_C}{C_C}}=\sqrt{\frac{0.4 \times 10^{-3}}{0.5 \times 10^{-6}}}=28.28\Omega[/latex] Parameters of OH Transmission lines Inductance[latex]L_1=1.5[/latex] mH/km and Capacitance [latex]=C_1==0.015\mu F/km[/latex] Surge impedance of the line [latex]=Z_1=Z_2=\sqrt{\frac{L_1}{C_1}}=\sqrt{\frac{1.5 \times 10^{-3}}{0.015 \times 10^{-6}}}=316.22\Omega[/latex] E= 20 kV Junction voltage [latex]\begin{aligned} E_j&=\frac{2E \times \frac{1}{Z_C}}{\frac{1}{Z_C}+\frac{1}{Z_1}+\frac{1}{Z_2}} \\ &= \frac{2 \times 20 \times \frac{1}{28.28}}{\frac{1}{28.28}+\frac{2}{316.22}}\\ &=33.93kV \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 214 The ABCD parameters of a 3-phase overhead transmission line are [latex]A=D=0.9\angle 0^{\circ}[/latex], [latex]B=200\angle 90^{\circ}\Omega[/latex] and [latex]C=0.95 \times 10^{-3}\angle 90^{\circ}[/latex]S. At no-load condition a shunt inductive, reactor is connected at the receiving end of the line to limit the receiving-end voltage to be equal to the sending-end voltage. The ohmic value of the reactor is
solution: [latex]X_{L,SH}=\frac{B}{1-A}=\frac{200\angle 90^{\circ}}{1-0.9}=2000\angle 90^{\circ}\Omega[/latex]

Question 215 A balanced delta connected load of (8 + j6)[latex]\Omega[/latex] per phase is connected to a 400
V, 50 Hz, 3-phase supply lines. If the input power factor is to be improved to
0.9 by connecting a bank of star connected capacitor the required kVAR of the
of the bank is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Q_C &=\frac{P_1(\tan \phi _1 - \tan \phi _2)}{3(2 \pi f V_{ph}^2)}\;\;...(i) \\ P_1&=\frac{3V_L^2}{Z} \cos \phi _1 \text{ for } \Delta \text{ load}\\ &\text{Star capacitor bank,} \\ V_{ph}&=\frac{V_L}{\sqrt{3}} \\ \text{where, } V_L&=400V \\ Z&=8+j6,\; |Z|=10 \\ \phi _1&=\tan ^{-1}(6/8) \\ \cos \phi _2 &=0.9 \\ &\text{Substitute in equation (i)} \\ Q_C&=10.2 \text{ kVAR} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 221 A transmission line has a total series reactance of 0.2 pu. Reactive power
compensation is applied at the midpoint of the line and it is controlled such that

power transfer limit of the transmission line is
solution: [latex]P_{ss}=\frac{1 \times 0.98}{0.1}=9.8\;pu[/latex]

question:
Question 222 A power system consists of 2 areas (Area 1 and Area 2) connected by a single tie
line. It is required to carry out a load flow study on this system. While
entering the network data, the tie-line data (connectivity and parameters) is
inadvertently left out. If the load flow program is run with this incomplete data
solution: For load flow study to converge there must be one slack bus in the system. As while entering the network data the tie-line data is not considered, two areas will now be treated as separate areas, hence, two slack bus (one in each area) is required.

options.A: The load-flow will converge only if the slack bus is specified in Area 1
options.B: The load-flow will converge only if the slack bus is specified in Area 2
options.C:
The load-flow will converge if the slack bus is specified in either Area 1 or
Area 2
options.D: The load-flow will not converge if only one slack bus is specified.

Question 227 The conductors of a 10 km long, single phase, two wire line are separated by a
distance of 1.5m. The diameter of each conductor is 1 cm. If the conductors are
of copper, the inductance of the circuit is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} L_{ab}&=0.4 \times \ln \left ( \frac{d}{r'} \right ) mH/km\\ &=0.4 \ln \left ( \frac{150}{0.7788 \times \frac{1}{2}} \right ) mH/km\\ &=2.3815 mH/km\\ &\text{For 10 km long line}\\ L_{ab}&=23.815 mH/km \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 229 A 50 Hz alternator is rated 500 MVA, 20 kV, with [latex]X_{d}[/latex] = 1.0 per unit and [latex]{X_{d}}''[/latex] per unit. It supplies a purely resistive load of 400 MW at 20 kV. The load
is connected directly across the generator terminals when a symmetrical fault
occurs at the load terminals. The initial rms current in the generator in per unit is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P_{3-\phi (p.u.)}&=V_{p.u.}I_{p.u.} \cos \theta \\ P_{p.u.}&=\frac{400}{500}=0.8p.u.\\ (\because \; \text{Base MVA }&\text{=500 MVA})\\ P_{actual}&=400MW\\ \text{since, }P_{p.u.}&=1\angle 0^{\circ} p.u.\\ \therefore \; I_{p.u.}&=0.8\\ E_g''&=1\angle 0^{\circ}+j0.2 (0.8\angle 0^{\circ})\\ &=1.01\angle 9.09^{\circ}p.u.\\ I_f''&=\frac{1.01}{0.2}=5.05p.u. \end{aligned}[/latex]
